title: coronavirus homework app google classroom
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'If you rate this one star we won't have online school,' one review for Google Classroom statesSchool children in Europe have taken a lesson from pupils under coronavirus quarantine in&nbspChina by flooding a homework app&nbspwith bad reviews in an effort to&nbspforce&nbspit offline.Google Classroom has seen a significant surge in demand as an increasing number of schools shut down amid strict containment measures designed to stifle the spread of the&nbspCovid-19&nbsppandemic. The remote working app allows teachers to create classes, distribute assignments and communicate with pupils through video or text chat.It is believed that spamming the learning tool with one star reviews will cause it to be removed from app stores and&nbsp therefore suspend online classes.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe tactic&nbspwas first used by students in China earlier this month with the&nbspAlibaba-owned&nbspapp&nbspDingTalk. The coordinated campaign by children in&nbspWuhan, China, saw&nbspDingTalk's&nbsprating drop from 4.9 stars to just 1.4 stars, however the app remained online.A slew of bad reviews for Google Classroom has seen its rating fall from 4.3 stars to just 2 stars on the Google Play Store in recent days.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government's four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?If you rate this one star we won't have online school, stated one reviewer posting on Friday.Dislike so we don't have to do work for coronavirus break please, stated another.Similar reviews were left on Apple's App Store, though the rating still remains relatively high.Google classroom is a means for evil, one review stated. It provides a way for teachers to overwhelm students with superfluous amounts of work in times of crisis such as the current coronavirus.Despite the efforts, the popular learning app remains online and will likely continue to do so even if the campaign continues.&nbspA spokesperson for Apple told&nbspThe Independent&nbspthat negative reviews alone would not&nbspcause an app to be removed.&nbspCreated with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemSchools across&nbspEngland, Scotland, Wales and Northern Ireland will close from Friday, following the lead of dozens of other countries across Europe and Asia.Many schools had already begun preparing for teaching pupils remotely through virtual education, using various online learning resources and educational apps.It is not yet clear when schools will reopen but the UK government said the closures will remain in place for the foreseeable future.GCSE and A-level exams will also not take place as planned in May and June, with education secretary Gavin Williamson describing the situation as increasingly challenging.The UK has seen more than 3,200 confirmed cases of the Covid-19 coronavirus, resulting in 144 deaths.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus jaguar land rover production suspended uk
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘The company will work towards an orderly return to production once conditions permit’Car giant Jaguar Land Rover is to suspend production at its UK plants because of the coronavirus crisis.The company said production will be temporarily halted over the course of next week, with the intention to resume on April 20, subject to review of the “rapidly-changing circumstances.”A company statement said: “As a responsible business, Jaguar Land Rover is operating in line with advice from the NHS and Public Health England to minimise the spread of the coronavirus, while implementing plans to safeguard its business continuity.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“The company will work towards an orderly return to production once conditions permit.Coronavirus: How to work from home when you have children“Currently, Jaguar Land Rover’s manufacturing plants in Brazil and India continue operating. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Historic rivals join forces with £100,000 donation to vulnerable communitiesManchester City and Manchester United have joined forces to donate a combined sum of £100,000 to local food banks in the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.Each club will donate £50,000 to the Trussell Trust’s 19 food bank centres in the Greater Manchester area in order to help vulnerable communities affected by the outbreak.The gesture follows co-operation between United and City fans’ food bank campaigns, whose match day collections outside Old Trafford and the Etihad have been interrupted by the suspension of the football season.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesIn a joint statement, City and United said: “We are proud of the role our supporters play in helping local food banks and recognise the increased strain likely to be placed on these charities by the impact of coronavirus.&nbsp“At a time of challenge for our community, we are pleased to come together with our fans to help vulnerable members of society in a City United.”Neville and Giggs offer their hotels to NHS staff to sleep in for freeRoman Abramovich to pay for NHS staff to sleep in Chelsea hotelNeville hits out at prime minister Johnson over coronavirus messagingRachel Macklin, senior operations manager of the Trussell Trust, said: “As the coronavirus pandemic develops, more people than ever may need help from food banks across our network.&nbsp“This situation presents a huge additional pressure on already overstretched resources. We may start to see a reduction in food donations and volunteers may become unavailable if they are in the at-risk categories or are self-isolating.“We’re working closely with our network to understand each food bank’s situation, offer guidance, and work out how we can best support them.“We know we won’t be able to do this alone, so we are truly grateful for the support Manchester United and Manchester City are showing local food banks.”The latest football headlines direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus supermarkets uk staff depots food
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Government temporarily suspends competition rules after shelves stripped bare by panic buying&nbspSupermarkets will be able to collaborate to ensure shelves are stocked with food throughout the coronavirus pandemic after the government relaxed competition rules on Thursday night.Responding to an extraordinary surge in panic buying that saw many shops stripped bare, ministers announced that supermarket chains will be allowed to pool their resources such as delivery depots and vans from next week as part of plans to keep the nation fed.Companies are usually forbidden from working together in order to prevent shoppers from getting a bad deal.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesBut as supermarkets were forced to implement rationing after anxious consumers stockpiled essentials to prepare for an extended period of self-isolation, the government was forced to act.Under the emergency rules, food retailers can share data with each other about stock levels, cooperate to help keep stores open and coordinate closure days to allow more time for restocking.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government’s four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?From Friday, delivery drivers will be able to drive for up to 11 hours a day rather than 10 hours.It came after the prime minister used Thursday’s coronavirus briefing to urge people to be “reasonable” when buying groceries.“As I said before, we’ve got good supply chains farm to fork –&nbspthere’s no reason for the shops really to be empty,” Mr Johnson said.“Please be reasonable in your shopping, be considerate and thoughtful for others as you do it”.George Eustice, the environment secretary, met with supermarket bosses on Thursday to hammer out a plan to deal with the problem, saying afterwards that the government would “do whatever it takes to help them feed the nation”.“By relaxing elements of competition laws temporarily, our retailers can work together on their contingency plans and share the resources they need with each other during these unprecedented circumstances,” he added.“We welcome the measures supermarkets are already taking to keep shelves stocked and supply chains resilient, and will continue to support them with their response to coronavirus.”No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. A number of major chains introduced rationing as stocks in some stores ran dry.Why people are panic buying toilet paper, according to an expertThe competition watchdog welcomed the new rules but warned firms not to take advantage of the coronavirus pandemic to boost profits.The Competition and Markets Authority said it “will not tolerate unscrupulous businesses exploiting the crisis as a ‘cover’ for non-essential collusion”.“This includes exchanging information on longer-term pricing or business strategies, where this is not necessary to meet the needs of the current situation.”Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - number of films, TV shows and books have been cited as ‘predicting’ a pandemicFans of Disney animated film&nbspTangled&nbsphave noticed a curious coincidence between the movie and the ongoing coronavirus pandemic.&nbspIn the film, Rapunzel spends her days locked away in a tower from the rest of the world – or rather, the kingdom of Corona.Fans have pointed out the irony as they self-isolate to help slow down the spread of Covid-19.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesActor Tom Hanks, who has been self-isolating with his wife Rita Wilson after they both tested positive for coronavirus,&nbsprecently joked that he no longer loved one of his typewriters, because the make was a Corona.Earlier this month, fans of&nbspThe Simpsons&nbspclaimed something similar, as they pointed out an episode from season four that depicts a global pandemic.In the episode “Marge in Chains”, a news report announces fears of the “Osaka Flu”.Another scene shows a visibly infected Japanese factory worker coughing into a package, which is then sent to the United States.Most of the residents of Springfield get sick as a result.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the title: coronavirus vaccine supercomputer ibm summit ai covid 19
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.IBM Summit found 77 drug compounds in just a couple of days, which researchers say 'would have taken months on a normal computer'The world's most powerful supercomputer has made progress towards understanding how to stem the spread of the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic, offering faster 9potential routes towards developing an effective vaccine.IBM's Summit computer was deployed by the US Department of Energy to simulate how different variables react with the virus.Researchers at the University of Tennessee used the vast computing power to run 8,000 simulations of how different compounds might impact the virus's infection process.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe research uncovered 77 compounds, such as medications, that could be used to impair Covid-19's ability to infect people.Summit was needed to rapidly get the simulation results we needed. It took us a day or two, whereas it would have taken months on a normal computer, said Jeremy Smith, Governor's Chair at the University of Tennessee and the principal researcher in the study.&nbspThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government's four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?Our results don't mean that we have found a cure or treatment for Covid-19. We are hopeful, though, that our computational findings will both inform future studies and provide a framework that experimentalists will use to further investigate these compounds.&nbspOnly then will we know whether any of them exhibit the characteristics needed to mitigate this virus.On Friday, the global number of confirmed cases of Covid-19 passed 250,000, which have resulted in more than 10,000 deaths.The supercomputer, which is the size of two tennis courts,&nbsphas previously been used in research ranging from Mars landings, to understanding the origins of the universe.Capable of performing over 200 quadrillion calculations per second, IBM's Summit is described as the Formula One of supercomputers and is 1 million times faster than the most powerful laptop.IBM said Summit would continue to be used for providing ground-breaking technology for the betterment of humankind.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: coronavirus youtube amazon prime netflix streaming quality internet outage down
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Industry expert warns video game platforms pose ‘substantially greater threat’ in terms of internet outagesAmazon Prime Video and YouTube will reduce the quality of streaming on their platforms in Europe in order to help internet infrastructure cope with a&nbspsurge in traffic resulting from the Covid-19 coronavirus pandemic.The move follows a similar announcement from Netflix&nbspfollowing a request from European Union commissioner Thierry Breton for streaming services to lower the resolution of their content to prevent internet&nbspgridlock.“We are making a commitment to temporarily switch all traffic in the EU to standard definition by default,” YouTube said in a statement.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesA spokesperson for Prime Video said the platform was working with local authorities and internet service providers “to help mitigate any network congestion”.Increased strain on the internet will likely increase over the coming weeks. From Friday, schools across the UK will close for the majority of students, leaving millions more at home using video streaming and online gaming platforms.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government’s four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?Concerns about widespread outages and critical services going down prompted BT to offer assurances that its broadband network would be able to cope with the added demand.“The UK is one of the world’s most advanced digital economies, so we overbuild our networks to compensate for our love of high-definition streaming content, video gaming and other bandwidth-hungry applications,” Howard Watson, BT’s chief technology officer, wrote in a blog post on Friday.“The Covid-19 outbreak is causing changes to the way our networks are being used. We’re monitoring those changes carefully to make sure we can respond rapidly if needed. However, the UK’s communications infrastructure is well within its capacity limits and has significant headroom for growth in demand.”​Other industry experts have warned that the measures may not be enough to prevent more outages, with GlobalData director Emma Mohr-McClune calling on other major bandwidth consumers to take similar action.Online video game platforms have already seen huge spikes in users in recent weeks – a trend that is expected to continue as the crisis progresses.&nbspDesktop gaming client Steam broke its all-time record for the highest number of concurrent users over the weekend, seeing over 20 million gamers use the platform at one time.Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem“Although video streaming represents the lion’s share of residential internet traffic in Europe, interactive online gaming is a substantially greater threat in network overload terms. Any mass market spike in activity will have significant consequences for vital government and market functions in Covid-19 lockdown&nbspmode.”​Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: foxtons coronavirus covid 19 tenants letting self isolate
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.‘If you have coronavirus or have symptoms it cannot and indeed should not impact your landlord’s plans,’ estate agent tells tenantEstate agent Foxtons told a tenant with coronavirus symptoms who was self-isolating to leave their home so potential buyers could view the property.Despite NHS guidance that anyone who may be infected should stay at home, Foxtons told the tenant that potentially having the virus was not acceptable grounds to restrict access to their home for viewings.“If you have coronavirus or have symptoms it cannot and indeed should not impact your landlord’s plans,”&nbspthe company said in an undated email seen by The Independent.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe message&nbspcontinued:&nbsp“Your obligations as a tenant to allow access for saleslettings viewings as per clause 11.2 of your tenancy agreement, which I’ve enclosed, are very clear.”The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government's four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?NHS guidelines tell anyone who has symptoms of coronavirus, however mild, to stay at home. People who live with someone who has symptoms are told to stay at home for 14 days because symptoms of the virus take some time to develop.Foxtons’ move may also have put the viewers of the property unwittingly at risk of being infected by the virus which can remain floating in droplets in the air for three hours after someone has coughed and can survive on plastic and stainless steel surfaces for two to three days.Foxtons admitted that its actions “fell well short” in this instance. The estate agent said it had apologised “unreservedly” to the tenant and offered them compensation.“We are taking the Covid-19 outbreak extremely seriously and we have reiterated to our staff that whatever the situation, anyone’s self-isolation should not be interrupted,” Foxtons said.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by email“We continue to do our utmost to ensure all customers’ needs are met during these challenging conditions.”The incident comes as Londoners prepare for an enforced lockdown period of self-isolation at home, while the UK death toll rose to 144.The pandemic has also highlighted the precarious situation of many private-sector renters who can be evicted from their homes without any reason needed from their landlord.In response to mounting calls for reform, the government this week announced emergency legislation banning evictions during the period of national emergency.But campaigners have called for more support including a rent holiday for those whose earnings are impacted by the pandemic.What rights do you have if you can't pay your rent due to coronavirus?David Cox, chief executive of the lettings industry trade body ARLA Propertymark, said: “If a tenant is self-isolating, an agent should avoid entering the property.“It’s important for agents to be sensible and reasonable while thinking of their tenants and their own health.”He advised agents to make “reasonable, regular checks” before arranging a viewing of a property.“Ask the tenants and the inidual viewing the property if they have returned from an impacted area, have a high temperature, a recent dry cough or have had contact with anyone who has symptoms. If they answer yes to any of these, then the agent shouldn’t conduct the viewing.Property inspections should be postponed unless they are absolutely necessary, Mr Cox said. If the work is vital, then they should ask tenants if they have had any symptoms or contact with someone who has symptoms. If not, then the work should go ahead but with added hygiene checks, thorough cleaning and use of disposable gloves.The trade body has issued guidance to lettings agents to help them deal with Covid-19.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: coronavirus young people not invincible world health organisation tedros adhanom ghebreyesus
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'This virus could put you in hospital for weeks, or even kill you,' says director-general amid concern young people dismissive of riskYoung people are not immune to coronavirus and are at risk of serious illness or death as well as putting their elders in danger if they do not avoid socialising, the World Health Organisation has warned.A “significant proportion” of patients treated in hospital for Covid-19 around the world were aged under 50, the WHO said, amid concern the gravity of the pandemic had not been grasped by many.“Today, I have a message for young people: You are not invincible”, said the organisation’s director general,&nbspTedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesSpeaking at a media briefing on Friday, he stressed: “This virus could put you in hospital for weeks, or even kill you.&nbsp Even if you don’t get sick, the choices you make about where you go could be the difference between life and death for someone else”.The dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government’s four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?More than 10,000 people worldwide have died of coronavirus since the outbreak began in China late last year. The number of cases globally has now topped 210,00, the WHO confirmed.The elderly and people with underlying health conditions are most at risk of falling seriously ill with coronavirus.But health chiefs in Italy, the worst affected country, have reported a growing number of younger patients requiring hospital treatment.About 12&nbspper cent of those who have been treated in intensive care in Italy are aged between 19 and 50, according to official figures released last week.Speaking separately to&nbspMr&nbspGhebreyesus on Friday,&nbspWHO senior adviser&nbspBruce Aylward said on Friday he was concerned young people were dismissive of the threat posed by the disease.“One of the things that terrifies me now is, as this is spread in the west is, there’s this sense of invulnerability among millennials,” he told Time magazine. “We don’t understand why some young healthy people progress to severe disease and even die, and others don’t.”The warnings came came as Boris Johnson’s&nbspgovernment ordered all pubs, restaurants and gyms to close on Friday night, in response to concerns that many people were failing to heed social distancing advice.Addressing the nation from Downing Street, the prime minister&nbspsaid “literally thousands of lives” would be saved if the UK public scrupulously observe advice to shun social gatherings where the virus could be spreadNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Then someone just went “pop”’West then delays telling Swift the lyric, explaining: “It says, uh... and the funny thing, when I first played it and my wife heard it, she was like, ‘Huh? What, that’s too crazy,’ and then when Ninja from Die Atwoord hear it, he was like, ‘Oh my god, this is the craziest s**t, this is why I love Kanye...’ and now, it’s like my wife’s favourite f***ing line... I just wanted to give you some premise of that.”He then says the lyric: “To all my Southside n***as that know me best  I feel like Taylor Swift might owe me sex.”Swift is heard laughing before she says: “That’s not mean.”“OK, well this is the thing why I’m calling you, because you got an army, you own a country of motherf***ing 2bn people, basically,” West says. “If you felt that it’s funny and cool and hip hop, and felt like it’s the College Dropout and Ye that you love, people would be way into it, and that’s why I think it’s super genius to have you be the one that says, ‘Oh I like this song a lot... this is cool.’”“I need to think about it,” Swift tells him. “When you hear something for the first time you need to think about it, because it is absolutely crazy-”Created with Sketch. It is, in a way - Swift's most political song to date addresses her heartbreak over America as she witnesses it in turmoil. She takes classic themes from her earliest work - white knights, red roses, princesses and high-school prom - and spins all of it into a metaphor for a perceived loss of innocence following the 2016 general election. Add the subliminal cheerleader chant - GO! FIGHT! Win!, and this makes for one of Swift's best songs of her career.While Red signalled Swift’s full-blown transition into pop music, she couldn’t resist putting the odd country twang on songs such as “We Are Never Ever Getting Back Together”, which mocks an ex for being snobbish about his “indie record label that’s much cooler than mine”. title: macbook air review keyboard magic butterfly apple price
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Apple's new laptop is familiarly sleek and returns with an unrivalled typing experienceApple has just revealed a new MacBook Air. It looks outwardly near-identical to the current model, but it offers better value, increased storage and faster performance. But even these things are not the game-changer: that’s the new keyboard.The pricing first: where the previous MacBook Air, on sale until just days ago, cost £1,099 and came with 128GB of internal storage, the entry-level Air is now £100 less, £999, and has 256GB of storage. There’s also a 512GB model available, with a faster processor, for £1,299. There are still lots of laptops out there for much less money, but this price represents good value. Note that Apple has education pricing for those in class as students or teachers, so it’s possible to get that price even lower if you qualify.The look is the same as before: sleek and classy. It comes in three colours, silver, space grey and gold. The space grey is the best: solid and businesslike without looking boring, though the gold, warm with a peachy hint to it, is also a head-turner.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesThe build quality of the MacBook Air is exceptional, an all-aluminium casing that’s sculpted to the slimmest of edges to make it easy to pick up. Like all MacBooks, and unlike many other laptops, you can open it with one hand, the build is so perfectly balanced. Other machines require a finger to hold down the keyboard as you open the lid or the whole thing swings up as it opens.This MacBook Air continues to have a power button with Touch ID built in – a fingerprint scanner that ensures your computer screen locks when you’re away from it and only unlocks to your finger. Apple Watch wearers can also use their smart timepiece to unlock the MacBook Air, which is cool. reprogrammed to interact with humans during a photocall at the new Design Museum in South Kensington, LondonA new Israeli Da-Vinci unmanned aerial vehicle manufactured by Elbit Systems is displayed during the 4th International conference on Home Land Security and Cyber in the Israeli coastal city of Tel AvivThe large glass trackpad, as before, is smooth and responsive, recognising multiple touches to navigate between windows, scroll through documents and so on.Like every other current Mac laptop, there are only two kinds of socket: a headphone jack and Thunderbolt USB-C for power or to connect accessories. The Air has two Thunderbolt USB-C ports. For other connections, such as USB-A, you’ll need an adaptor. That’s not always convenient, though it gets easier all the time as more accessories switch to USB-C, and it helps to keep the Air thin.The MacBook Air has been preposterously slim and light since it was first unveiled by Steve Jobs in 2008 when the then-CEO slid it out of an envelope to an admiring crowd. It was so much thinner and lighter than the competition that it drew gasps of excitement. Over the next decade it slipped behind, especially in terms of the screen resolution, though that’s been fixed. Now, the 13in display is bright, rich and superbly high-resolution.Apple releases iPad with 3D scanner and a trackpadApple and Netflix pull out of SXSW over coronavirus fearsAnd then there’s the new keyboard. Apple keyboards were traditionally outstanding, using a scissor-switch mechanism, with lots of travel and a great feel. Then, a few years ago, Apple changed to a whole new system, using a butterfly mechanism. The first-generation of this was quite noisy, but this was overcome in subsequent versions. But then, problems arose which led to keyboards being replaced as users complained that there wasn’t the same reliability.Last year, on the MacBook Pro 16in, Apple introduced the Magic Keyboard – a name taken from its desktop wireless keyboard – which changed everything. The new keys were quieter, more stable and had more travel – a full 1mm. That’s not quite as much as the keys moved before the butterfly landed, when it was 1.2mm. But it was enough, and it was a revelation.It’s the same here. Using the new keyboard subtly transforms the typing experience. It’s not that the butterfly keys were bad: unless they failed, they worked well and were comfortable to use.But as soon as you use the new Magic Keyboard, you recognise how comfortable and inviting it is. The downside is it’s quite hard to go back. Having typed this review on the MacBook Air keys, I picked up a previous Air to make a comparison. As soon as I started typing, my fingers told me I was missing the new experience. The keys on the old Air, which I had used happily before, just couldn’t match the luxurious and satisfying feel of the new one. The gentle scoop on the top of each key that helps your fingers find the right place to touch, the crisper inidual backlighting to make typing in a less bright room a breeze and the clearer lettering on each key – all of which are small, subtle improvements that Apple has made with the Magic Keyboard – add up to something big.The processor has been improved on the latest models with a 1.1GHz dual-core Core i3 processor on the £999 model and a 1.1GHz quad-core Core i5 chip on the £1,299 version.In practical terms, this means that the Air is a real performer. Not that it was a slouch before, but it handles tasks easily. It’s true, the MacBook Pro is still the go-to laptop for those doing advanced video processing or running other power-hungry programs. But the Air is now very fast and effective. To the extent that many customers may ask whether they really need to spend £1,299 on the entry-level 13in MacBook Pro rather than a £999 MacBook Air that isn’t that far off. Sure, there are other extras in the Pro range, like the spiffy Touch Bar instead of function keys, and four Thunderbolt USB-C sockets instead of two on the Air, for instance.Battery life on the MacBook Air is exemplary: it just goes on and on all day where other laptops, including some MacBook Pro models, don’t last as long. It’s so good that you may not even think about checking how much charge is left in the battery. It gives a great feeling of peace of mind.The new MacBook Air is available for order now, with deliveries starting next week. It represents a big step forward for the super-slim Apple laptop, combining sumptuous good looks with real performance and, above all, an unbeatably appealing keyboard.Be inspired with the latest lifestyle trendsEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: oyster whale projects sustainability lottery funding
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The National Lottery Heritage Fund announced cash for five new projects focusing on Scotland’s seas and inland waterways and their habitatsProjects to restore native oyster beds and improve a whale trail are among those sharing in £1.33m of lottery funding.The National Lottery Heritage Fund has announced cash for five new projects focusing on the sustainability of Scotland’s seas and inland waterways and their habitats.They include £216,400 for a project to restore native oysters on a sea loch on the mid-Argyll coast by growing up to one million of them over five years to create a self-sustaining population.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOrca sets record with 5,000-mile journey from Iceland to BeirutUnprecedented number of critically endangered blue whales recordedLive whale washes up on Cornwall beachHow to eat out sustainablyCharity organisation Sea Wilding will be working with volunteer group Craignish Restoration of Marine and Coastal Habitats (CROMACH) to grow the oysters in floating baskets to be moved to trial seabed sites that were once widespread in the loch.Another grant, of £443,000, will be used to redevelop Edinburgh attraction Dynamic Earth’s Ocean Galleries into a “contemporary immersive exhibition” designed to inspire and educate more than 250,000 people a year about Scotland’s deep-sea heritage.Caroline Clark, Scotland director of the National Lottery Heritage Fund, said: “As we celebrate Scotland’s Year of Coasts and Waters, there has never been a better time to raise awareness of the important role our marine heritage has in the future of a sustainable environment.“Not only is the direct conservation we fund vitally important but we hope that through our projects there will be increased awareness of how and why we need to change our behaviours in order to protect our future.”Meanwhile, a £250,000 funding boost will help the Hebridean Whale and Dolphin Trust Centre in Tobermory on Mull be redeveloped as the Gateway to the Hebridean Whale Trail, which links 33 sites across the west coast of Scotland.Coronavirus outbreak exposing ‘precarious nature of UK welfare system’The project will strengthen the Hebridean Whale Trail, including new interpretation in the centre, films and a programme of activities to educate visitors, in both English and Gaelic, on the marine heritage of the Hebrides.Elsewhere on the west coast, the natural habitat of the Plock parkland near the Skye Bridge will be improved to provide an important green space for the local community with the help of £196,100 award.A £228,100 grant to the Gateway to Gigha project will help protect the natural and cultural heritage of the island through a new community initiative encouraging more people to travel without their car and providing foot Leith Banana Flats, belted out the ballad by Scottish duo The Proclaimers as an act of community spirit through their windows as they practised&nbspsocial distancing.Ms Murray, 32, told The Independent she and her husband were “overwhelmed” by the response to the video they posted on their restaurant’s Facebook page.She said: “Our restaurant Borough is very much a part of the community Premium.‘Emergency disease outbreak will often be adequate justification for taking exceptional measures,’ MPs sayEnhanced measures to curb the coronavirus&nbspoutbreak will “significantly curtail” fundamental freedoms in Britain – but can be legally justified, MPs have said.Parliament’s Joint Committee on Human Rights&nbspsaid it would be thoroughly scrutinising new laws and action taken by authorities.“Some measures could significantly curtail inidual rights,” MPs wrote in a briefing paper issued on Thursday.Sharing the full story, not just the headlines“There are other practical and economic impacts on iniduals who cannot work due to self-isolating, or due to sickness – some of these measures will affect certain groups more significantly than others. &nbspHow to be productive if you have to work from home during coronavirusWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?The dirty truth about washing your handsShould you be taking paracetamol or ibuprofen to treat coronavirus?What are symptoms of coronavirus – and where has it spread?It came as the government formally announced details of an Emergency Coronavirus Bill setting out measures aimed at slowing the spread and supporting the NHS and workers.Police have already been given new powers to detain anyone with suspected symptoms and force them to undergo testing or be quarantined, although senior officers insisted they would “not be used willy nilly”.Amid rumours of a nationwide “lockdown”, Gavin Williamson, the education secretary, said the government was ready to take “incredibly tough decisions” but had no immediate plans to shut down restaurants or force people off the streets.The Joint Committee on Human Rights said any action must comply with both international law and the European Convention on Human Rights (ECHR) but added: “An emergency disease outbreak will often be an adequate justification for taking exceptional measures provided that such measures are justified title: eu nationals settlement scheme home office settled status brexit
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Home Office refuses people EU&nbspsettled status on grounds of&nbspeligibility&nbspfor first timeHundreds of EU nationals have been told they don’t have the right to stay in the UK after applying for post-Brexit immigration status, figures show.The latest statistics on the government’s EU settlement scheme, published on Thursday, show 300 people have been refused settled status. These iniduals will not have a right to live in Britain after the deadline of June 2021, unless they successfully appeal the decision.The number remains proportionately small, as there have been nearly 3 million applications processed overall, but it marks a considerable jump from the previous monthly figures, when just seven people had been refused.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesAt that point the refusals were all on the grounds of criminality, but most of the latest refusals were due to issues around eligibility –&nbspusually because the applicant has been unable to provide the relevant&nbspdocumentary&nbspevidence.While the number is still proportionately low, campaigners have raised alarm at the sudden increase, and it is likely to prompt concern around difficulties more vulnerable people face when obtaining evidence.Charity helping children in care stay in UK has to stop taking casesEU settlement scheme delays leave people unable to get jobsNine out of 10 EU settlement scheme appeals successful, data showsWithout physical proof of our status, EU citizens like me live in fearThe Home Office said officials had made every attempt to obtain the necessary evidence before refusing applications, and that decisions to refuse were not taken lightly and signed off at a high level.Maike Bohn, co-founder of campaign group&nbspthe3million, told The Independent she was concerned by the fact that while there had been no refusals on eligibility grounds before February 2020, there was now a sharp rise.“This is hard to explain. We urgently need more explanation from the Home Office as to why those cases have been refused,” she said. “It is concerning that as soon as the UK left the EU we see people being refused settled status.”Christopher Desira, immigration solicitor at Seraphus law firm, said there were likely to be more and more refusals beyond criminality grounds, which may worry a lot of people in uncommon family arrangements, which tend to be the most complex applications.&nbspHe also raised alarm over the gaps in free outreach and advice services that are likely to form due to the coronavirus outbreak, which may cause problems for those receiving requests for further information from the Home Office, but not know how to respond, and called on the Home Office to pause any refusals until the emergency is over.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailLiberal Democrat home affairs spokesperson Christine Jardine called on the government to back the Private Members’ Bill she tabled last month that would guarantee the rights of EU citizens in the UK.Home Office presides over 100 data breaches in EU settlement schemeShe said: “EU citizens in the UK have been living under a cloud of uncertainty for far too long. They are our families and friends, our colleagues and carers. They must have the right to stay.&nbspEven before the coronavirus crisis, we were warning that tens of thousands of EU citizens will be left without settled status when the Conservative government’s arbitrary deadline hits next year.“That would leave thousands of people effectively undocumented and at risk of eviction, detention and even deportation. It will be a new Windrush scandal on an even bigger scale.”The Home Office figures show that overall, there have been more than 3.34 million applications to the scheme up to the end of February 2020.Minister for future borders and immigration Kevin Foster said: “EU citizens have made huge contributions to our country. It’s good news over three million have now been granted status and will be able to continue to call the UK home for decades to come.”Tory MP admits EU settlement scheme sometimes 'doesn't work as well as we expect'The department&nbspsaid it had&nbspa wide range of support was&nbspavailable online, over the phone and in person to help EU citizens apply for settled status.Earlier this month, the department announced a further £8m of funding to award 57 charities to help vulnerable EU citizens apply, on top of £9m announced for the same cause last April.However many charities in receipt of the original funding said they had been forced to cut back on their services due to uncertainty as to whether the funding would continue beyond the month of March – accusing the Home Office of leaving the announcement until the “last minute”.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: us olympics when coronavirus delay usa swimming team athletes
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.The organisation encourages postponement of the Games until 2021&nbspUSA Swimming has asked for the Tokyo Olympics to be delayed by one year amid the coronavirus pandemic, the organisation wrote in a letter addressed to the&nbspUS&nbspOlympic &amp Paralympic Committee (USOPC).&nbspTim Hinchey said athletes on the team have struggled to train for the upcoming Games, which are anticipated to start in July 2020.&nbsp“Everyone has experienced unimaginable disruptions, mere months before the Olympic Games, which calls into question the authenticity of a level playing field for all,” Mr&nbspHinchey wrote. “Our athletes are under tremendous pressure, stress and anxiety, and their mental health and wellness should be among the highest priorities.”It was also stated that&nbspthe “right and responsible thing to do is to prioritise everyone’s health and safety” during the global pandemic over participating in the Olympics.&nbspSharing the full story, not just the headlinesA one-year delay was requested by the team for the Olympics to instead happen in July 2021 once the toll of the virus subsides.&nbspThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhat is the difference between Covid-19 and the common cold and flu?Can face masks really protect you against coronavirus or flu?The UK government’s four stages of fighting coronavirus explainedWhat are symptoms of coronavirus -- and where has it spread?“There are no perfect answers, and this will not be easy however, it is a solution that provides a concrete path forward and allows all athletes to prepare for a safe and successful Olympic Games in 2021,” he wrote.&nbspThe USOPC said earlier on Friday it had not expressed a preference on postponing the Games or given a deadline&nbspto the&nbspInternational Olympic Committee (IOC) to make a final&nbspdecision.&nbsp“I think we would concur with them that we need more expert advice and information than we have today to make a decision,” Susanne Lyons, USOPC’s board chair, said on a conference call with reporters Friday, according to the Washington Post. “And we don’t have to make a decision. Our Games are not next week or two weeks from now. They’re four months from now. I think a lot may change in that time period. So we are affording the IOC the opportunity to gather that information and expert advice, and at this point in time we do not feel it’s necessary for us to insist that they make a decision.”USA Swimming is a huge draw when watching the Olympic Games given the level their athletes perform at, with former&nbspswimmers including Michael Phelps, who is the most decorated Olympian of all time. So the organisation speaking out against the continuation of the Games comes as&nbspa huge blow for the IOC while it weighs the difficult decision.Jacob Pebley, a swimmer on the 2016 US Olympic‘s team, released a statement about why the Games should be postponed this year.&nbspTeam USA and role models for hundreds of thousands of young athletes, attend Olympic Trialsthe Olympics in good conscience?” he wrote. “To do so would fly in the face of all emerging evidence and best practices for social distancing and protecting the health of vulnerable communities.”US Gymnastics team has not publicly taken a position on if the Olympics should be postponed this year.&nbspThe British Olympic Association (BOA) recently said it would not “endanger the health” of its athletes by encouraging them to train for the Games if it was not in their best interest to do so.&nbsp“We can be categorically clear that we will not endanger the health and wellbeing of the athletes or wider delegation at any point,” the BOA said.&nbsp“It is imperative to preserve competitive integrity for athletes, but it is clearly only wise for athletes to continue to prepare for the Games where it is safe and appropriate to do so, within relevant Government and public health guidelines.”But the organisation said it&nbspstill respected the IOC and its decision-making process when ultimately deciding if the Games should be postponed or continue.&nbspNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Chinese city of Wuhan, where the coronavirus&nbspis believed to have&nbsporiginated, remains under lockdown after nearly two months, even as the world’s attention has shifted to other hotspots.These pictures show – through windows and on balconies and rooftops – how Wuhan residents holed up in their apartments are getting on with their lives. People can be seen hanging laundry. Children play. One man eats noodles. Another smokes a cigarette.Chinese officials and some public health experts have credited the draconian confinement measures on a city of 11 million, and much of Hubei province, of which it is the capital, with slowing the spread of the disease and turning the tide of infection across China.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesOther countries, including Iran, Italy and the United States, are struggling to manage their outbreaks.&nbspBut even as the number of new reported cases stops in Wuhan, people in the city remain suspended in an isolated new normal.Residents are forbidden from venturing out of their homes even to buy food, which must be delivered. Schools and most shops remain shut, and roads are virtually empty.&nbspChinese doctors celebrate closure of last coronavirus hospitalScientist whose chilling report convinced Trump of coronavirus threat China ‘set to declare victory over virus’ as Xi makes first Wuhan tripOn Tuesday last week, Wuhan closed the last of 14 makeshift hospitals set up to treat and isolate patients after the outbreak had overwhelmed the city’s healthcare system.&nbspIn a dramatic sign that the situation is improving, president Xi Jinping made a high-profile visit to the stricken city, his first since the outbreak began.Nearly 50,000 coronavirus cases have been reported in Wuhan, with around 2,500 deaths. However, China this week&nbspreported no new domestic cases – meaning the strict isolation measures have been working.&nbspBut the outbreak has also exacted an unquantifiable psychological toll on people in Wuhan as families cope with loss, children are unable to go to school or play outside, and livelihoods are imperilled as people can’t go to work.Reporting by&nbspCarlos Garcia and Tony Munroe, ReutersNo hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Jogger demonstrates how to stay fit during isolationIn the age of enforced isolation, Elisha Nochomovitz still found a way to run a marathon - back and forth on his balcony in France.He ran 26.2 miles on his 23ft&nbsp(7-metre) balcony in six hours and 48 minutes in what he said was a physical and mental challenge.He has shared his feat in Balma, a suburb of the southern city of Toulouse, as a way “to extend my support to the entire medical personnel who are doing an exceptional job” during the coronavirus outbreak.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesHe also said he wanted to show others that it is possible to stay fit as virus containment measures tighten around the world - while also lightening the mood.“It was about launching a bit of a crazy challenge and bringing a bit of humour, to de-dramatise the confinement situation,” he said.Created with Sketch.Before and after photos show impact of coronavirus around the world Show all 20Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, Bethlehem1020 Gateway of India, Mumbai1320 Church of the Nativity, BethlehemHe suffered nausea during his run, and was worried his neighbours would complain about the constant pounding of his footsteps.The French authorities are still allowing people to go outside for “inidual sports” like running, if they sign a special form explaining why.But the number of joggers has multiplied in recent days, amid exceptionally warm weather, and French authorities are now worried that too many people are still out in the streets.Mr Nochomovitz said: “If everyone thinks the same way and does the same thing, we'll all find ourselves outside and that won't help anything, and the message that we need to stay confined at home will have had no impact.”He said he had already been training for a marathon, and “I needed to assure myself that I could still run 40 kilometres whatever the condition”.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. title: bbc sport relief charity finishes
story: The first was to postpone it, like the football and rugby, until such time as the theatre plugs and worthy schemes about “bringing the outside world to pensioners” with breathing dficulties, looked a bit less reckless.The second was to say: “Stuff it, as a one-off gesture to the British public, at this time of crisis, every single penny raised will be spent in Britain.”But Auntie would no more do that than re-run all eight series of Love Thy Neighbour, in The One Show’s slot.So they took option C and just ploughed on regardless, from pm, Friday, with the usual too-many-cooks line-up of Paddy McGuinness, Alex Scott and Gary Lineker, who made this earnest pledge: “We promise we’ll spend tonight’s money with such care on the most vulnerable.”Well, you’d hope so, wouldn’t you. And you’d also hope they take more care than they did with the actual production, which started to betray a “will-this-do ” attitude with almost its first caption of the night.“Dermot Munaghan.” And the next one: “Colston Smith.” .A foretaste of what was to come, because the event had technically unravelled within the first hour when Lineker had to introduce a comedy sketch about VAR and the  World Cup final.First it appeared, then it vanished. So Lineker explained the punchline: VAR had not just found in England’s favour it had decided to award the  World Cup to Scotlandand Euro  to Wales.Then the sketch suddenly reappeared again and took six minutes to reach its bloody, teeth-pulling conclusion: “I’m going to change my name to Jamie VAR-dy.”In such circumstances, you can sit and hope the rest of Sport Relief moves, inspires and thrills with a perfect blend of laughter, compassion and entertainment.And I can also hope Scotland are going to win the next World Cup. It ain’t going to happen.Sport Relief is never ever over quickly, ’cos there are a whole load of BBC formats to be put through the ringer, like Line Of Duty, and far too much dancing, featuring everyone from Lineker and McGuinnes to a “social media influencer”, called “HRVY”, which wasn’t another spelling mistake. I think he’s just an RSHOL.At ious other points in this back-of-a-fag-packet evening: Hockey player Sam Quek took , football penalties against a short fat bloke, from point-blank range, and contrived to miss more than a quarter of them. Mel Giedroyc farted on a Question Of Sport special. Rylan accused Romesh Ranganathan of being over-exposed, before playing Andy Murray at crazy golf. And they flagged up an Action Line number, for people who were feeling “emotionally vulnerable”, after the Killing Steves parody, which may have been the most benevolent gesture in the event’s history.What really irks about Sport Relief, though, is that, evencompassion fatigue has never been more of a problem, they’ve decided it’s a triumph before it’s broadcast and the “Best Bits” Sunday show is all ready to go.Corporate backing also means there’s little risk of them not beating the previous total either, which, I hope, doesn’t sound like I’m diminishing the sincere efforts of the public.If there’s one thing I’ll remember about Sport Relief , however, it’s the contribution of David Beckham, who, infor a y advertorial for his new MLS franchise and some crashing product placement , offered two entire people the chance to attend an Inter Miami game and win a shirt signed by such global talents as Lewis Morgan and A J DeLaGarza, who’s played  entire games for Guam.There are moments when the generosity and humanity of celebrities simply overwhelms me.This wasn’t one of those moments.Bloke.CHANNEL  seemed to have all bases covered for its hugely entertaining new dating show Five Guys A Week, at least in terms of complete bellends.So, crammed into a semi-detached house in St Albans, hoping to win the heart of its owner Amy, it had: Christian, whose job “isn’t as glamorous as it sounds” . Uber-woke Glen, from accounts. A stuntman called Michael, who seemed to have mistaken the show for SAS: Who Dares Wins and voluntarily withdrew on day two. Mad, goggle-eyed surfer Trystan, who appeared to be casing the joint for a “kill room”. And the lowest form of le known to any single thirtysomething man – the bloke with the acoustic guitar, Scott, who used to be a bank manager, but now earns a living as a country and western singer and will be performing under the stage name Johnny Cashpoint,he’s got an ounce of sense.The five were chosen for their ability to get right on the viewers’ nerves rather than real boyfriend potential, obviously.And it made for a cracking hour of TV, because they all competitively fancied the pants off Amy, who looked like a younger and much hotter Camilla Parker Bowles,you can imagine such a thing.The show’s greatest strength, of course, is also its biggest format failing, as I’d imagine no one wanted any of them to win.In the event, however, it came down to a straight fight between the lesser of two evils and, probably wisely, Amy chose cocky Christian, who’s looking to whisk her off for breakfast in France, ahead of grovelling Glen, who, rather than looking for “the Michelle Obama to my Barack”, should probably be aiming for the Michelle Collins to his Ian Beale.Five Guys A Week, C, tonight, .pm.The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “What caused the cancellation of six Wimbledon championships in the s ”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which city in north-east England shares its common name with the body of a ship ”Spin To Win, Phillip Schofield: “What Saturday night TV show is Anton du Beke most famous for ”Hunted, Dan: “Who painted the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel ”LISA NANDY wasn’t born stupid. She volunteered to be, by standing for Labour Party leader.It means noisily backing every woke cause of the day, until their interests collide, as they did spectacularly on last Tuesday’s Good Morning Britain, where Piers Morgan hit her with two innocuous-sounding questions.“Are babies born either male or female ” and “Would you be happyUsain Bolt and Floyd Mayweather self-identied as women, spent a year having testosterone treatment and competed against women ”Correct answers: Yes and no.But Lisa couldn’t say that for fear of offending either the transgender or feminist lobbies.So instead she blathered, lied, evaded, shouted, demanded an apology from Piers , accused him of laughing and describing transgender people as “grotesque”and at one point muttered: “I don’t know what . . . I don’t know what, well, you know, I don’t know what.”Others would’ve let her off the hook at that point, as she was almost crying at her own stupidity by then. Chunk didn’t.To his eternal credit he ignored two ad breaks and kept up the pressure for a spellbinding  minutes that only ended when Nandy offered to settle the issue of whether Floyd Mayweather should be able to box women by “setting up a commission”.To which Piers responded: “It’s not a commission issue, it’s a common sense issue.”But that, as a wise man once said, is the problem with common sense, Piers. It’s not all that common.Ian Wright: “At this stage, I think three points is three points.”Jamie Redknapp: “Switching off from football is always beneficial sometimes.”Piers Morgan effectively ending Lisa Nandy’s Labour leadership bid on TV’s most consistently entertaining show, Good Morning Britain.Saturday night eye balm from BBC’s Ireland: Edge Of The World. Larry David ending up in the “ugly section” of Tiato’s restaurant, on Curb Your Enthusiasm.Sky’s Breeders managing to make a comedy about children bearable.And John Humphrys’ opening curveball on Saturday’s Celebrity Mastermind: “Name ” “Bez.” “Occupation ” Pass.This Morning, Holly Willoughby: “What should a ‘support neighbour’ look like  ’Cos my mum’s older than me.”Andyour mum isn’t older than you, self-isolate immediately.THIS week’s winner is Future Stewie, from Family Guy, and Chief Medical Officer Professor Chris Whitty.All those self-defined “experts” whose coronavirus response is framed not by their humanity or expertise but the desperate need to be proved right.Every selfish moron in the country being filmed panic-buying toilet rolls.Firebrand left-wing stand-up Guz Khan taking the gig economy advertising shilling from Uber Eats.The comically awful use of Photoshopped throwback pictures in BBC drama The Split.And the never-ending queue of fantasists and egomaniacs at E’s Sex Clinic, like third person-speaking Drew, who announced: “I’m not having vanilla sex. That’s not what the Drew brand is about. Le’s too short, man.” The shorter the better . . . man.The Sex Clinic, Matt: “I think I need to learn to love myself.”Five Guys A Week, Glen: “My talents aren’t obvious. They’re not tangible things.” On account of the fact they don’t exist. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus thinking revive blitz spirit
story: People have lost loved ones and will continue to do so, and the virus is going to cause an unprecedented, global economic crisis that could see businesses go under, job losses, and severe financial dficulty for those already living hand to mouth.You’ll no doubt have read the latest bad news.So, solely for the purposes of this article, forgive me , instead, I focus momentarily on trying to find the admittedly few green shoots poking through the rubble.For, unlike Brexitwhich caused bitter ision among communities, the coronavirus pandemicis already bringing communities together that, in the modern age of “smart” devices absorbing our attention, had perhaps become slightly detached from each other in recent years.Professor Steven Taylor, author of The Psychology of Pandemics, says: “People need reminding that they can cope with this. They are resilient. You aren’t going to like it, but you’ll get through it.“You can compare it to the Blitz. People got through the Blitz. It was very stressful but they did it.”My elderly mother lives just a few roads away from me and, like so many with similarly vulnerable relatives, I’m making sure she’s OK.“Just pop a tin of Spam through the letterbox, and I’ll be fine,” she joked in reference to her time growing up during World War Two.But yesterday, three of her immediate neighbours — one of whom she’s never met — put notes through her door to say she should give them a callshe needed anything.In times of such crisis, our first thought is naturally of ourselves and our immediate loved ones.But it seems the upsideof the world slowing down and re-grouping might be that, no longer distracted by the busyness of our normal working days, we will “look up” and “reach out”, as they say in business circles, to those in our communities who might need help.There are plenty of people who already do sterling work in their area, but the onslaught of the coronavirus will perhaps lead to everyone now doing their bit.Quite right too. But the onus can’t solely rest on the shoulders of iniduals, so it’s only right the Government has stepped up to offer some practical help to businesses that will suffer throughout the coming weeks and months.Boris Johnson’s advice that people shouldn’t go to pubs cafes theatres etc is understandable in health terms, but will leave businesses facing a critical downturn in custom through no fault of their own.Yesterday, London restaurateur James Chiaini urged him to “crack open the war chest” and allow local businesses to stay afloat while simultaneously channelling efforts towards helping out in their immediate communities, and it seems that new Chancellor Rishi Sunak has listened.In James’s case, he has staff on hand and lots of food supplies, so instead of shutting down because there are no customers, he and other restaurants across the country could potentially now operate a batch-cooking and delivery service for those in need.Equally, the skill sets of many other businesses can be channelled into providing much-needed, state-funded help where it’s required.And the Government shouldn’t stop there. It should repurpose certain facilities too.Last week, it was reported that the £million Defence Medical Rehabilitation Centre in Loughborough, Leics, is currently seriously underused because only current personnel can access it and only  have done so in the past  months.Madness. At the very least, it should be thrown open to all injured veterans who currently have to go through the overstretched NHS.Or how about temporarily repurposing it as a treatment centre for anyone who could benefit from its facilities, thereby alleviating some of the pressure on local hospitals The Government is clearly in uncharted territory right now because it is dealing with an unprecedented situation.But a continuation of joined-up thinking on how best to get us through this critical phase in our history will ensure that Britain’s enviable “Blitz spirit” is encouraged and kept strong for as long as it needs to be.PRINCE Harry is now back behind the closed doors of his rented Canadian mansion, licking his wounds after his public humiliation at the hands of phone pranksters.During a chat with what he thought was climate change activist Greta Thunberg and her father, Harry pledged his support to the non-existent island of “Chunga-Changa” and failed to question why the hoaxers wanted to ship penguins to the North Pole when they’re actually native to the South Pole.Poor Harry.Still, it perhaps explains why, despite attending Eton, he got D at geography A level.Indeed, on all our faces in these challenging times.Heartfelt congratulations to her and husband Chris.FORMER All Saints star Nicole Appleton has given birth to her second child, a girl called Skipper, at the age of .“After hiding my pregnancy for the last nine months – which was so dficult and keeping her a secret from all my friends – I can finally announce our incredible news!” she wrote on Instagram.Fascinating. It’s one thing wearing a big coat out in public, but how do you hide a growing bump from “friends” Has Nicole, whose boyfriend is Stephen Haines, been in pre-emptive self-isolation for the past few months Or is it simply that her petite frame and enviably taut stomach muscles meant she just looked like the rest of us after a big meal Personally speaking, by month seven I looked like I had a medicine ball stuffed up my frock.STORMZY reportedly ripped up his travel plans after meeting Victoria’s Secret model Yasmine Aisha Khala Holmgren backstage at a gig in Stockholm.The pair are said to have holed up in a hotel room for two days where, according to a friend of the grime star, they wanted to spend “quality time” together.That’s one way of putting it.A NEW biography about former Commons Speaker John Bercow claims that he didn’t speak to a female aide for the entirety of a nine hour flight – because he was furious that his toothpaste had been confiscated at airport security.Quite what it had to do with her is anyone’s guess.But one imagines she was grateful for the prolonged period of peace.HANNAH SMITH, a -year-old mum of one, has been handed a suspended sentence after admitting the crime of harbouring a criminal.Her boyfriend, violent robber Luke Harvey, scaled the wall of HMP Sudbury in Derbyshire, where Hannah was waiting to drive him to Skegness for a weekend away.They were later pulled over by police and Harvey, , had ten months added to the -year sentence he received in .Leicester Crown Court was told that the couple had now split up.Presumably, actually spending time together proved too much.HERE is yet another photograph of the singer and actress Jenner Lopez looking sensational at . Sigh.Apparently, this latest photo-shoot, which highlights her enviably toned and tanned legs in a tuxedo-style leotard, is to promote her new footwear line.Is she wearing shoes We hadn’t noticed. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: rishi sunak coronavirus economy meltdown
story: Some have already lost their jobs. Others must now give theirs up to look after their kids, with schools closing.It may be hard for politicians to grasp, but many ordinary people have no savings to tide them over.They are broke NOW. They need to feed themselves and their families NOW.Not at the weekend. Not next week.Even those not yet made redundant by this global economic collapse are petried about how bad this could get.The pub industry alone says hundreds of thousands of jobs will be lost imminently without immediate help.Other governments have stepped in. Why has ours been so slow Devising a new system to get tens of billions in lost wages into the right hands is complex. We get that.We also think the “universal income” idea is an ill-considered and permanently ruinous fix.But promises, and a temporary ban on evicting renters, won’t quell the fear.This virus is not the fault of the workers, nor the Government whose draconian restrictions are sound.But with the economy in total meltdown, only the Government now can get Britain paid.Do it today, Rishi.CLOSING schools was grimly inevitable but right. It always seemed odd to keep them open while telling everyone to stay home.The Government must fulfil its pledge to ensure kids on free school meals are fully funded to get fed.We pay tribute to the NHS staff, delivery drivers and social carers whose often low-paid work is so essential that their children WILL still be looked after in school.And our hearts go out to the teenagers whose GCSEs and A-levels will be postponed indefinitely.This is an unprecedented nightmare, blighting their childhoods.We can only help each other endure it.IMAGINE the evil of using a deadly ­pandemic to spread fake news furthering your political or commercial agenda.It should no longer shock us after the Salisbury poisonings.But Kremlin trolls are sowing panic online to undermine the West’s Covid- strategies.Let’s remember that, next time our leaders have to make nice with Putin at the G.Meanwhile, conspiracy cranks say hand sanitiser causes cancer — and charlatans claim their “yoghurt suppositories” or vitamin pills “cure” the virus.Where do they do this with near impunity  That’s right . . .On Facebook, which talks such a good game about policing its site — but is always found wanting.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
