title: coronavirus key workers children school
story: KEY workers whose children will be allowed back to school as they play a crucial role in Britains fight against coronavirus have been named by the Government. The working heroes include nurses, police officers and delivery drivers and their children will be exempt from the decision to close classrooms from Monday to stop the spread of the deadly bug.A No source confirmed to The Sun Online only one parent needs to be eligible for kids to be allowed back to class.The Government today named nine sectors critical to the COVID- response - Health and social care Education and childcare Key public services Local and national government Food and necessary goods Public safety and national security Transport and Utilities, communication and financial services.Families have been urged not to leave their children with grandparents aged over  in order to protect the elderly, who are most at risk from the deadly bug.Education Secretary Gavin Williamson said: We still need to have our critical infrastructure that continues to work and .Click here to see the full list of workers.It comes as:The Government has today laid out a detailed list of people defined as key workers.This includes doctors, nurses, midwives, paramedics, social workers and care workers.It also means other frontline staff such as support staff, producers and distributers of medicines and medical equipment.Includes nursery and teaching staff, social workers and special education professionals.Includes courts staff, religious staff, undertakers and people in charities delivering key frontline services.Journalists and broadcasters are also on the list because of the crucial service they provide in keeping the public informed.Government staff who are essential to the response to COVID- or delivering essential public services such as the payment of benefits.Those involved in food production, processing, distribution, sale and delivery as well as those essential to the provision of other key goods Includes police and support staff, Ministry of Defence staff and the armed forces.Firefighters, National Crime Agency staff and border security, prison and probation workers are also includedThose who keep air, water, road and rail services operating.Staff needed for essential financial services, IT and data which are needed to continue during the coronavirus response.Infrastructure workers who maintain oil, gas, electricity and water supplies are also included.This also features key staff in the civil nuclear, chemicals, telecommunications, postal services and delivery, payments providers and waste disposal sectors.Workers are advised to check with their employerthey are included.The announcement as Boris Johnson spells out his warplan to beat coronavirus.Yesterday, Britains death toll rose to  with a total of , confirmed cases.Boris told the nation he is absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country and the tide can be turned within three months.He said: Im conscious as the days have gone by that people will want to know how long were expecting them to keep it up.I think, looking at it all, that we can turn the tide within the next  weeks and Im absolutely confident that we can send coronavirus packing in this country.But onlywe all take the steps that weve outlined, that is vital, thats how were going to reduce the peak and once weve achieved that and I think that we will,we take the steps Ive said, then the scientic progress that weve been making will really start coming into play.Boris added British experts expect to start trials for a vaccine against Covid- within a month, although expectations are that a vaccine will take at least a year.He said: To give you an idea of what is coming down the track, were in negotiations today to buy a so-called antibody test, as simple as a pregnancy test, which can tell whether you have had the disease and its early days, butit works as its proponents claim, then we will buy literally hundreds of thousands of these kits as soon as practicable.It comes as the Queen issued a rallying cry telling Brits to pull their weight in the fight against COVID- and avoid the pub and panic buying.She said: I am certain we are up to the challenge.Our history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one.The Monarch is currently self-isolating in Windsor Castle having cancelled public events in Cheshire and Camden.Her message to protect the most vulnerable comes as supermarkets were put under immense strain amid panic-buying Brits.Shoppers have been pictured brawling over toilet paper and booze after fears the UK could be put under lockdown.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.The key workers announcement was originally meant to be made yesterday, but Health Secretary Matt Hancock revealed on Question Time last night the list had been slightly delayed.He said: The list will be published tomorrow. We know weve got to get it out tomorrow because schools are closing to everybody  on Monday.This is a decision nobody wanted to take. This is an awful situation.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: defeat coronavirus nation play part
story: We all need rapidly to get a grip.The Government’s advice, backed by its scientists, has been clear enough: Avoid pubs and restaurants, where the virus can so easily spread.Stop the brainless panic-buying and hoarding which strips shelves of essentials ALL of us need — especially OAPs, exhausted NHS workers and the low-paid.Yet some pubs remain packed, notably in London where two-thirds of the latest deaths occurred.Some young people think a pint is worth the risk.Old folk reckon Britain saw off the Nazis, so they won’t be cowed by a microscopic bug.We can understand it . . . but both attitudes are delusional and irresponsible.It won’t just be their problemthey catch Covid-.They could infect an old or sick person, who dies.And the NHS will have to cope with all of it.People must stay at home.And though The Sun has always been a friend to our pubs, Boris Johnson must ignore his liberal instincts and shut themneed be.Supermarkets, meanwhile, insist the food supply is perfectly adequate IF people shop sensibly and considerately.But queues snake around the block at dawn.Selfish shoppers buy enough loo roll, pasta and medicine for months.It is insane, unnecessary and must stop. It causes hardship. It makes others panic.“Our nation’s history has been forged by people coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal,” says the Queen.She is absolutely right.Most ARE taking seriously their safety and other people’s. Too many are not.Do your bit. Remain home wherever possible.Only buy supplies you need.Britain has prevailed before by uniting in a common cause. It is vital we do it now.MORE soothing words from Boris for ­panic-stricken businesses — but where is the money to pay workers’ wages Yet another day passes, with thousands more jobs lost.Firms WILL stand by staffthey can afford to, PM.But your Chancellor must write cheques today or the weekend will be carnage.THE Windrush generation were shamefully treated by the Home Office.They were wrongly deported to the Caribbean like illegal migrants when they were perfectly entitled to be here.To learn that wasn’t just incompetence but “institutional ignorance” over race is even more shocking.But when Priti Patel, a British-Asian Home Secretary, cracked the whip, the Left backed the pen-pushers.What strange loyalties.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britains brexit negotiator self isolating after showing symptoms of coronavirus
story: BRITAINS Brexit negotiator David Frost has been forced to self-isolate after showing symptoms of coronavirus.The deadly virus has wreaked havoc on both sides of the trade talks, after EU negotiator Michel Barnier tested positive for COVID- yesterday.Mr Frost is following government advice and isolating himself after displaying symptoms for the virus, according to Bloomberg.His isolation follows swtly on from Mr Barniers twitter announcement on Thursday afternoon that he had tested positive for coronavirus.The two Brexit negotiators have not seen each other since the last round of trade talks two weeks ago.Another round of talks were scheduled to take place in London this week but were quickly postponed after COVID- tightened its grip on Britain and Europe.The number of confirmed cases in the UK skyrocketed yesterday for , with  deaths.Europe closed down the borders of the previously pass-port free Schengen Area to bar entry to international travellers.The death toll in Europe has surpassed Asia.It comes as:Boris Johnson has refused to extend the transition period even in light of growing crisis.He said earlier this week that the end of the transition period was enshrined in law and he would not consider changing it.The UK formally left the EU on January  but will continue to follow the blocs rules until December . Both sides have said that talks will continue through other ways, including video conference, to keep steam behind the crucial discussions.To receive our Covid- newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.

title: 1 4m brits self isolate monday coronavirus
story: AROUND . million Brits are expected to be told to self-isolate on Monday due to coronavirus - as the death toll hits .Health Secretary Matt Hancock said that those who are classed as vulnerable will be contacted with the specic actions they need to take.Experts say that older people and those with underlying health conditions are more susceptible to the deadly bug, which has infected at least , in the UK.The Government is urging people to social distance - including steering clear of pubs and restaurants - in order to stop the spread of the bug.But pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars in recent days.Mr Hancock told Sky News: The first thing were going to do is set out exactly what conditions that applies to.We expect about . million people to then get a communication from the NHS to say that they are part of this and what they need to do.Many of these people have pre-existing health conditions and so will be very worried right now, and I understand that, and theyll need very specic sets of action. For instance, how do you go about still getting your chemoyou have cancer whilst also social-distancing If you have cancer its particularly important to stay away from other people, but you also of course have got to keep going with your chemotherapy.It comes as:To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Mr Hancock added: These are some of the most dficult and challenging cases so well be getting in contact with them, butpeople think that they are on this list and dont receive a communication from the NHS, then they also need to get in contact.So that is under way, the money was announced for it yesterday. A combination of money to the NHS and money to councils because theyve got a very big part to play in keeping people safe.It comes as an army of , retired nurses and doctors have been told “Your NHS Needs You” in the battle against coronavirus.Medical students and trainee nurses are also being invited to join the fight — while members of the public have been askedthey can help, too.The Prime Minister said he expects the tide to be turned in the fight within  weeks, as he urged the public to follow social distancing advice and for businesses to stand by your employees.But he implied that this is onlythe public heeds the social distancing guidance, saying: I know its tough, I know its dficult... but please, please follow the advice.Meanwhile, the Queen issued a message to the nation which said the UK is entering a period of great concern and uncertainty, adding that our nations history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one.The death toll in Italy rose to ,, overtaking the total number of deaths so far registered in China.Back in the UK, the toll reached , with around four in  of all deaths so far in London. A glimmer of good news came from Mr Johnson, who said British experts expect to start trials for a vaccine against the virus within a month, although expectations are that a vaccine will take at least a year.He also said a game-changer antibody test was coming down the track which could identy whether somebody somebody had become immune to the disease so they couldto their daily le.The PM also pledged to massively increase testing to up to , a day, which combined with collective action and scientic progress he said would save many, many thousands of lives.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus covid 19 super rich testing kit private jets leo mckinstry
story: JUMPING the queue, expensive testing kits and escaping to distant sanctuaries in private jets - this isnt just isolation, this is elite, super-rich isolation.As the coronavirus pandemic sweeps across the world, some celebrities, millionaires, and members of the business class seem to believe that their wealth can be used as a form of vaccination while the rest of us face the deadly risk of infection.Such behaviour is entirely against the public spirit of the moment. This is a time for unity and for respecting others, especially the most vulnerable.As the Queen put it yesterday in her admirable statement: “I am reminded that our nation’s history has been forged by people and communities coming together to work as one, concentrating our combined efforts with a focus on the common goal.”As the emergency deepens, abuse of privilege should play no part in our national response.But that is exactly what is now happening, as is graphically demonstrated by the saga of private Covid- tests kits.One of the biggest problems the Government faces is the shortage of capacity for testing.To prevent the current system from being overwhelmed by demand, NHS policy is only to test people with a “high chance” of having the illness, such as those who have ed from high-risk countries or are displaying symptoms.Even doctors and nurses working in the front-line are not routinely tested.But to evade such official restrictions, a growing number of the rich and famous are forking out for private coronavirus kits, which can cost anything between £ and £.According to one report this week, more than , wealthy figures in Britain have ordered such kits.Dr Mark Ali, director of the Harley Street clinic, said: “We have private iniduals – some recognisable names there – and we are testing lords and ladies and even doctors and dentists who are worried about catching the disease.”It is the same story of privileged access in the US, where, just as in Britain, shortages of supplies mean that many health care workers and sick people are unable to get diagnoses.But some stars seek to bypass rules that limit tests to those most at risk.A huge controversy erupted this week at the news that eight top NBA basketball teams has been tested, making a mockery of the rationing.Bill de Blasio, the mayor of New York, spoke for much of the public when he said that “an entire NBA team should not get tested for Covid- while there are critically ill patients waiting to be tested. Tests should not be for the wealth, but for the sick.”On both sides of the Atlantic, this two-tiered approach is wrong on so many levels.It is a deep insult to healthcare workers. It is profoundly isive.And it does not lessen the burdens on the NHS here in Britain, as some apologists pretend.Those who test positive will still have to be treated in the health service, since the British private medical sector does not have the resources for this crisis.Selfish and irresponsible, the Covid-test queue jumpers are the equivalents of the supermarket stockpilers or the social distancing refuseniks who still insist on going down to the pub.During the Second World War, when the Blitz spirit was at its peak, there was fierce hostility to rich iniduals who tried to cheat on rationing regulations or avoid national service.The same contempt should now be shown to those who try to dodge the rules that promote fairness.But it is not just in testing where the narrow self-centredness of the rich can be found. They use their wealth to insulate themselves in other ways.Some are buying special private medical care, like intravenous infusions of vitamins and minerals to boost their immune system.Lansherhof, a private medical facility at the London Arts Club, reported this week an  per cent increase in enquires for its Immune Plus Support Infusion, which costs £.The rich are also using private jet travel to avoid the rest of the public as they conduct business or fly to remote havens.Inquiries for international flights by private jets are estimated to be up nine-fold since the outbreak began, while Hong Kong International Airport reported this week its busiest day for private jet activity.Nor do the rich have to endure the normal airport ordeal suffered by other passengers.A spokeswoman for Quintessentially, a concierge company for millionaires, said: “Members who are travelling commercially are choosing to book elite services at airports, not your typical first-class lounge.For example, private terminals where guests are greeted and given their own suite.Check-in, customs and security are all done privately and guests are taken to the doors of the aircraft.Members can request for the jetty to be cleared so they minimise the interactions with other passengers”.Most Brits have no choice over where they live in the midst of this crisis.But that is not true of the wealthy who can find sanctuary in one of their many properties or rent out an expensive rural bolt-hole.Some are now paying £,-a-month for a luxury base in the Cotswolds.Nor does self-isolation have to be the imprisoning experience that it is for ordinary citizens.The rich can bring in private chefs for their dinners, or expensive tutors for their children.The company Tutors International, which provides elite tuition services, says it has seen “a massive upswing in requests” since the outbreak began.The elite even have luxury face masks. The fashionable Airinum Urban Air Mask costs £ and claims to protect “against airborne particles as small as .mm.”But in this rarefied world, problems are faced by the elite that would never be considered by others.Wailing that she now has now chance to show off her expensive jewellery, one female financier in London says: “I’m just not sure when my next ball will be.”The experience of the affluent is in dramatic contrast to the misery faced by people at the other end of the scale.While the rich cocoon themselves, it is the wage-earners, the straitened households, the poor and the unemployed who are now in the eye of the storm.Our society is just beginning to realize the terrying consequences of this disaster, where the mounting death toll is matched by economic meltdown.Vast numbers of people – from hotel cleaners to airline cabin crew, from bar staff to retail assistants – are going to lose their jobs.The ranks of the five million self-employed will be decimated. Small businesses across the country will collapse.Food banks are already running short of supplies, while the plight of the homeless – who cannot isolate themselves on the streets – is desperate as shelters close.At worst, our prosperous civilisation could slide into a kind of modern feudal structure, with only the aristocracy at the top enjoying a decent standard of living.At a press conference in the White House on Wednesday, President Trump was asked whether “the well-connected go to the front of the line”.He replied philosophically: “You’d have to ask them that. Perhaps that’s been the story of le.”But it should not be that way, especially when mankind is facing one of its darkest hours.We should all be in this together.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: social distancing must be in place year coronavirus
story: BRITAIN must remain in lockdown for up to a year to prevent the NHS being overwhelmed, the Government’s doomsday research warns.Scientists have advised Boris Johnson that shutting schools and telling Brits to stay out of pubs and workplaces for only a few months is not enough to beat the coronavirus. They suggest alternating between severe and less strict measures, with the harshest curbs in place on and off but for a total of at least six months over this period.The advice is included in evidence considered by the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies, published online yesterday.Sir Patrick Vallance, the Government’s Chief Scientic Adviser, said the analysis had played a “considerable role” in shaping restrictions.One of the reports warns just isolating sick households and cocooning vulnerable groups is “very unlikely to prevent critical care facilities being overwhelmed”.And it adds: “It was agreed that a policy of alternating between periods of more and less strict social distancing measures could plausibly be effective at keeping the number of critical care cases within capacity.“These would need to be in place for at least most of a year.“Under such a policy, at least half of the year would be spent under the stricter social distancing measures.”Dr Jenny Harris, the deputy chief medical officer, issued the warning — but said it was important kids still exercise.Speaking alongside PM Boris Johnson, she said: “The basic strand running through these measures is social distancing. That applies to children just as it does to the rest of us.”She said it was fine for siblings or children in “household groups” to play together.Dr Harris added that team sports should be avoided by both children and adults.The stark warning was issued in a document from a Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group, dated this Monday.But just three days later, the PM said the UK could “turn the tide” on the outbreak within  weeks.The experts say restrictions could be imposed or lted to control the spread of the virus and may y in dferent UK countries and regions at dferent times.However, they warn there is a risk of a second wave of infections later in the yearthe Government enforces too many restrictions at once and then lts them later.They also say school closures alone will have little impact on the epidemic and hit poorest families hardest.It could delay the peak by up to three weeks and reduce cases and deaths by five per cent.However, they also argue classroom shutdowns would be “most effectivestarted as early as possible” — a revelation likely to anger critics questioning why they were not shut sooner like in other European nations.Isolating sick households is predicted to reduce the peak of the outbreak by a quarter and deaths and cases by ten per cent.But getting people to work from home and avoid pubs, restaurants and cinemas has the greatest potential impact — reducing the peak by up to  per cent and deaths by  per cent.Researchers found Brits were most likely to catch coronavirus in family gatherings. The elderly were also at “high risk” at religious services and other get-togethers.Exeter University modelling suggests a major outbreak would last around four monthsno action was taken.Andsummer helps halt cases, it could lead to an even bigger — and deadlier — spike next winter.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page. That explains why ministers were keen not to halt all spread once the outbreak took hold.A previous study by Imperial College London showed failing to introduce severe social restrictions could have led to , deaths.Sir Patrick said: “This is an incredibly fast-moving, developing situation and as part of our collective efforts to give the clearest and most reliable scientic advice, SAGE has and continues to draw upon a huge range of experts and a huge range of evidence.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: family decking tear down south wales
story: Jamie Davies put up the large decking to give his family privacy in their South Wales garden.But when the -year-old applied for back-dated retrospective planning permission he was refused, and has to rip it out.Council planners slammed the £, decking as the most appalling thing as they kicked out his application to keep the superdeck at his £, home.Now the Davies family face legal action unless they rip out the decking - unless they can find a compromise with planners.A council planning committee heard no neighbours had objected to the garden frame in the development in Blaina.But councillor Bernard Willis raged: “If that was being built near my house I would be appalled.“I think it is a dreadful thing to be looking at and in my view we should not be approving this application.”The family wanted to add plants to hide the steel from view, but the application to keep it was thrown out by eight votes to seven.Dad Jamie, manager of a sports centre, said: We put the decking up to give privacy for the children while they play.The next step for us will be talking to the planning officers and seeing what we can do next. We dont know about an appeal yet.Councillor Lisa Winnett told Blaenau Gwent planners that she was in favour of the build.She said: “Many developments are quite similar.“I do not see an issue with the visual impact of thisplanting is done on the outside.”Garden decking became all the rage from the late s - with makeover show Ground Force getting the blame for the boom.Retailer BQ reported an increase in sales of the lawn alternative from £, in  to a staggering £million in .Presenter Alan Titchmarsh accepted the blame for the lawn cover-up - saying at the time: I am sorry, I know its everywhere these days.Last year we told of epic design fails are so bad that youll struggle to believe they actually happened in the real world.From a meaty marble dining set to hilarious advert blunders, we reveal the top picks of the worst creations designers contributed to.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pubs london closed coronavirus
story: PUBS, restaurants, and other venues in London will be ordered to close over the coronavirus surge.Boris Johnson chaired an emergency meeting this morning as the Government tries to find ways to battle the outbreak.Gyms, leisure centres and cinemas all across the capital are facing closures, with Boris expected to make the announcement at todays pm press conference.Shops are not expected to be affected in the move, but could be struck down laterthe outbreak fails to slow down.It comes amid growing concerns that Brits are refusing to social distance, and continuing to pile into pubs and clubs after work.Pictures have shown boozed-up Brits spilling out of clubs and bars as they continue to ignore government advice.The pub-goers have been slammed on social media after cases of the killer bug rose to , yesterday with  deaths in the UK.The Government earlier insisted that London would not be going on lockdown, and there were no plans to stop people leaving their homes.They also stressed that Brits will also not be confined to their homes as the UK death toll hit .It comes as:Matt Hancock had earlier pleaded with the public to follow Government advice, insisting it was the only way to get it dealt with in -weeks.He explained: “If people follow the advice, we can get through this quicker.“Evenyou dont think you are personally at risk because you are younger, which by the way isnt true, this affects everybody,you dont follow the advice we are going to have to keep these measures in place for longer.“For everyones sake I think everyone needs to pull together and listen to the experts.”Sadiq Khan has told Londoners to “stop travelling and avoid social interaction”.He said:  “People should not be travelling, by any means, unless they really, really have to.“Londoners should be avoiding social interaction unless absolutely necessary, and that means they should be avoiding using the transport network unless absolutely necessary.”Wetherspoons owner Tim Martin had earlier insisted his pubs would be open for the duration.Despite the pandemic, he said: I think that once you shut them down its very dficult.Supermarkets are very, very crowded. Pubs are much less crowded. Theres hardly been any transmission of the virus within pubs and I think its over the top to shut them.Thats a commercial view but also a common sense view.Piers Morgan hit back at his comments, labelling them insane stupidity.

title: coronavirus doctor photography competition scottish mountains
story: Dr Kenny Muir won the prestigious title with his stunning pictures taken in remote parts of Scotland.Dr Muir was labelled Scottish Photographer for the Year with his breathtaking photos.The stand-out picture was of Seilebost Gneiss, where he captured the Luskentyre estuary, framed by the snowy mountains of North Harris.He said: “I am shocked and delighted to have won this competition, particularly when surrounded by so many talented photographers.“Two of the winning images are part of a personal project to document the wilder side of Glen Affric, one of Scotland’s largest remnants of Caledonian Forest. I hope to highlight the importance of preserving and regenerating these areas of natural beauty.”His win comes as the confirmed cases of coronavirus continued to soar to , in the UK with  deaths.Dr Muir#s portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Dr Muir is currently fighting the outbreak of the deadly COVID- virus at Raigmore hospital in Inverness, Scotland.He said he would need to take a break from photography to focus all his efforts on keeping people alive and well.#As a hospital doctor I will be taking a break from photography to focus on current events, but really appreciate receiving the award.#His portfolio featured images from Glen Affric and the Island of Harris.Another standout shot was of one of the many small lochs deep within Glen Affric, capturing morning lighting hitting the native pinewoods after an evening of snow.The Scottish Landscape Photographer of the Year competition consists of a number of categories, including Landscape, Seascape, Urban, Monochrome, Four Seasons and Scottish Weather.Andrew Bulloch, from Edinburgh, won the Youth Category for the second year running, with his image of ‘The “Beast from the East” hits Edinburgh’.Andrew said: “The heavy snowstorms that hit the UK in March  were clearly visible as they swept across the city. I climbed to the summit of Arthur’s Seat to get the best viewpoint and had to get pulled out of a snowdrt on my way down.”Founder of the competition Stuart Low said in this tough times, he hoped the photos would give everyone some much needed joy.Stuart said: “In these dficult times ahead of us, we hope these stunning images will bring a little joy to everyone.”All the winning images will be showcased in a limited edition book that will be available from April .

title: prince harry meghan markle coronavirus lockdown text

Thousands of holidays have also been cancelled.There are also going to be millions of bored kids and teenagers now that the virus has closed all the schools.Chancellor Rishi Sunak began his speech at todays press conference saying: “To all those at home anxious about the days ahead. I say this: you will not face this alone.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Harry and Meghans message comes as the couple ed to Canada this month after completing their final engagements as Royals.The Sussexes had dramatically announced they were quitting the Firm in January - with their last day settled for March  after negotiations with the Queen.And it has been claimed the couple and baby Archie, who is ten months, are now self-isolating in their luxury North American home.With everything going on, it’s a lot to take in. Many of us may feel confused. Or alone, or anxious or scared...and in isolation, some of us may just feel bored, or that you don’t know what to do with yourself without your normal routine. It’s perfectly normal to be feeling any of these things.Our emotional well-being is challenged every day whether we realise it or not, but our lives are usually filled with distractions. Now with constantly changing COVID coverage, we are all adjusting to this new normal and the feelings that come with it.But here’s the good thing : Yes, there is isolation and physical distancing, but there doesn’t have to be loneliness.There are resources that can help us all through this process, and ways that YOU can become one of those resources. @crisistextline @giveusashoutinsta @kidshelpphone and @CTL_Ireland are organisations that need new volunteers now more than ever and have an open door for you to get the support you need.And for those of you who don’t feel comfortable texting with a stranger, reach out to your friends, family and colleagues. Phone calls and video conferencing are such a great way to feel more connected - askthey’re okay, tell them how you’refeeling, and use this time to really listen for the answer.If there is someone you know and are worried about, your text may be the thing that saves their le.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: french snatch lorries 130000 coronavirus masks
story: The cargo was being urgently ferried in a major boost for over-stretched UK medics battling coronavirus.But French border guards impounded the trucks after realising what was on board.They were acting on President Emmanuel Macron’s pledge to “requisition” all masks for his country’s fight.The seizure came just  hours after another British-bound vehicle carrying thousands of bottles of hand sanitiser was also held up on the other side of the Channel.UK officials were quickly alerted to both incidents.And after tense, top-level talks, the lorries were allowed to leave with all supplies on board.A government source said: “On Tuesday night, French authorities stopped the hand sanitiser and confiscated the lot. “On Wednesday night, it was lorries full of FFP face masks to protect staff.”To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.But a Whitehall source added: “Both incidents were dealt with relatively quickly.“There is a clear understanding between countries that only a united approach will tackle the public health emergency all countries face.“It appears to have been a misunderstanding, we’re confident it won’t happen again.”President Macron had promised on Twitter on March  that the French “will requisition all stocks and the production of masks”.Former Tory party leader Iain Duncan Smith said: “This shows you all you need to know about European co-operation.“Europe is in lockdown and each nation has been left to their own devices.”Paracetamol exports from Britain have been banned as ministers move to protect vital stocks.Officials have halted firms from shipping  key drugs abroad, including adrenalin, insulin and common painkillers.Health Minister Lord Bethell said: “NHS staff are going above and beyond to provide world-class care to patients and we are supporting them in every way we can.”Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: britain has more than enough loo roll for people to stop panic buying according to andrex manufacturer
story: Kimberly-Clark — which makes Kleenex and Andrex — assured The Sun that plants across the UK are working flat out to meet increased demand.Toilet paper has been flying off the shelves in chaotic scenes as worried shoppers stock up amid the coronavirus epidemic.Kimberly-Clark usually makes .million rolls a day at plants in Northfleet, Kent, and Barrow, Cumbria — and has now boosted production.A spokesman said: “There is just no need to panic buy. We make one billion loo rolls a year that’s enough to stretch easily around the country.“The trucks are going out replenishing stock all the time but the problem is that as soon as it’s going out people are buying it straight away and they just don’t need to.’’Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: north korea launches missile into the sea as kim jong un ramps up tensions
story: An unidentied projectile, that was later described as a short-range ballistic missile, has been detected just days after Kim Jong Un told the world that his country was coronavirus free.Japans coastguard has confirmed the launch, saying that it landed outside their exclusive economic zone waters, adding that the missiles appeard to be ballistic.The notorious hermit nation has seemingly taken advantage of the situation in neighbouring South Korea, Japan and China to send off what is believed to be a missile.The unknown projectile was detected flying into the East Sea according to South Koreas Joint Chiefs of Staff via Koreas Yonhap News AgencyThis is the third test this month, with previous launches having taken place on March  and .North Korea has been flaunting international treaties and bans on missile test after the second summit with Donald Trump fell through.Kim previously accused western powers including the UK of “illogical thinking” following calls for a top-level UN meeting over his hermit kingdoms last missile launch.Britain, Germany, France and Belgium all raised North Korea’s previous weapons tests before the Security Council branding them a provocative act which breaches global rules.In spite of reports indicating that coronavirus has killed hundreds of soldiers and unknown numbers of civilians in the impoverished nation, Kim has yet to formally acknowledge it.North Korean officials recently executed a quarantined patient who was not showing symptoms after he skipped out and went to a public bath. They shot him in the street upon his arrest in mid-February.Kim Jong-un has reportedly imposed military law to enforce a lockdown to combat the virus - despite the country not experiencing any confirmed cases.In a bizarre letter to South Korean President Moon a few weeks later, Kim Jong Un said his country felt sorry for their neighbour in a somewhat unsettling display of unity.The US has this week offered aid to help fight the spread of the virus in North Korea but has allegedly been rebuffed so far.On Friday, senior North Korean officials vowed to complete a general hospital in Pyongyang by October  to cope with the officially non-existent virus as instructed by Kim Jong-un according to state media.Earlier this week, Kim attended a ceremony to break ground for Pyongyang General Hospital and ordered the construction to be completed by the th founding anniversary of the Workers Party of Korea .

title: helping hand hero coronavirus
story: WE are living through the most extraordinary and terrying of times – with our lives at stake and our jobs at risk.While the medical world battles to bring the coronavirus epidemic under control, there are two things we can ALL give — our kindness and our time.Today The Sun is calling on all readers who are currently healthy to become Britain’s Helping Hand Heroes.YOU can make a real dference to those who are already affected by this terrible virus — by simply offering your time.An act of kindness, no matter how small, will help people suffering from Covid- symptoms and living in self-isolation.As Chancellor Rishi Sunak said at todays government briefing: “Now, more than at any time in our history, we will be judged by our capacity for compassion.“Our ability to come through this won’t just be down to what Government or businesses do, but by the inidual acts of kindness.Nancy says: “I can pass on tips about how to cope.“Just having someone listen and laugh with you is good.”She is encouraging other Helping Hand Heroes to think about the skills they can share over the phone or online to help people in their community.. MUM-OF-ONE Bessie Antclfe, , runs Bessie’s Cafe and Bistro in Sheffield.She is taking meals to her customers in isolation and needs help with deliveries.Bessie says: “Anyone on lockdown can call us and we will leave meals at the door.“If you want to get out of the house and are not showing symptoms, then helping out would be cool.”. MORE than  people have joined Kirsty Gill’s Facebook group to help the sick and elderly in Gillingham, Kent.Mum-of-three Kirsty, , and her army of volunteers will bring essential supplies to anyone unable to leave the house.She says: “We all need to come together.“I support The Sun’s campaign  per cent.“Help each other, do not exploit people. Show some kindness.”“The small business who does everything they can not to lay off their staff.“The student who does a shop for their elderly neighbour.“The retired nurse who volunteers to cover some shts in the local hospital.“When this is over, and it will be over, we want to look back on this moment and remember the many small acts of kindness.“We want to look back on this time and remember how we thought first of others, and acted with decency.“We want to look back on this time and remember how, in the face of a generation- defining moment, we undertook a collective national effort and we stood together. It’s on all of us.”More than a million over-s and vulnerable people are facing lock-in for  weeks within days.There have already been many inspiring stories of kindness.Schoolboy Jimmy-Dean Hudson, seven, is the perfect Helping Hand Hero.He spent his pocket money buying dozens of toilet rolls — then GAVE them away to elderly neighbours in Southend, Essex.Milkman Tony Fowler has been delivering loo roll and hand sanitiser and collecting prescriptions for elderly customers on his round in Melton Mowbray, Leics.Many elderly people are trapped behind closed doors, terried.Age UK’s advice line has seen a  per cent increase in demand, while The Silver Line has experienced a  per cent rise in calls from anxious older people in need of reassurance and friendship.Elderly people have already been swindled out of more than £, by coronavirus scammers, says the National Fraud Intelligence Bureau.Many older people are right to be wary of offers to run errands.So, please, only ask to help old folk you know and who trust you.THERE are lots of brilliant organisations, big and small, desperate for people to help out by donating their time.By being Helping Hand Heroes we can make Britain feel a better place.Try one or more of these ways to help an elderly neighbour:CARE PACKAGES: Drop a surprise one to a neighbour.Give them a call to say you have left it.FLYERS: Make some with your number on and give to neighbours so they can callthey need help.WHATSAPP: Join or start a community WhatsApp group to help vulnerable neighbours.GET CREATIVE: Design cheerful cards with your kids to send to care homes to boost morale.BUDDY UP: Create a buddy system to check in daily with an older person by phone to beat loneliness.FLOWERS: Place a bouquet on the doorstep of someone in self- isolation to brighten up their day.Don’t go in, just knock.OLD PHONES: Offer old mobiles to neighbours and buy them a cheap SIM so they can stay in touch.Clean properly first.NEWSPAPER: Let housebound people know about The Sun’s -week free delivery offer so they can keep up with the news in Britain’s favourite paper.TAKEAWAY: Order food for someone who is vulnerable or self-isolating so they do not have to cook.MEMOIRS: Ask older family members to write down their le story and read it to you over the phone to keep them occupied.But it is not just the elderly who need your help.With most schools closed, possibly until after the summer holidays, give a hand to a struggling mum or dad, too.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.BABYSIT: Leave a note under the door of a neighbour you know well, offering to look after the kids.FOOD BANK: Managed to find supplies at the supermarket Put some in the food bank basket as they are short of stock.SHOPPING: Help out a nurse or a health worker by popping to the shops for them.WALKIES: Offer to take a neighbour’s dog out, or pet sitthey are a key worker.DONATE: If you are working from home, consider donating the money you would have spent commuting to a charity that helps the needy.KEEP QUIET: It is tempting to do loads of DIY when you are stuck in the house — but turn down the volume.Let neighbours get a good night’s sleep.BINGE WATCH: Add more users to your Netflix and Amazon Prime accounts so friends can watch too.VIRTUAL PINT: At the end of a day working from home, hit the phone and check on your workmates or share a “virtual pint” on FaceTime.SMALL BUSINESSES: Support firms that are still trading in your community by buying gt cards.And we can all follow the advice of milkman Tony.He says: “In  years as a milkman I have never let anyone down and I don’t intend to now.“I know how a small act of kindness can make a huge dference to people who need a bit of help.”HISTORY tells us that battles are won by people – people with the determination to see things through to the end.Beating coronavirus is one of those battles that requires determination to the end.However, there is one weapon we need to see in greater use.It is the power of kindness.Set against the chaos of people fighting and jostling in supermarkets to claim the last pack of loo rolls is the example of the unknown shopper who overheard a gentleman asking for a pack of mince.There was none left on the shelves so she followed him out of the shop, insisting he took one of hers, at no cost.That is the sort of kindness we need to see right across the country.When all this has died down, will you be remembered as a hoarder or a helper Many people up and down our country need help right now: Those who are lonely because they are self-isolating, those who are ill, those who are frightened and those who are running out of money to pay bills or buy food.This is where charities and community groups can make a real dference – on the ground, on the front line, where people are in real need.But just at the time they are needed most, many charities themselves are struggling to survive.Their traditional means of fundraising have dried up.Social distancing means jumble sales and quiz nights are cancelled, the London Marathon, which raises so much for charities, is postponed and, just like businesses, charities are wonderingthey can survive.Perhaps the Government will realise the extent of this crisis in the voluntary sector and put in some money.Just a fraction of what is going to businesses would be transformational. So far this is not forthcoming.But this is where we can all get involved, show our kindness, help others and help ourselves.The National Emergencies Trust , set up after the Manchester Arena bombing and the Grenfell Tower fire, launched an appeal on Wednesday, brilliantly promoted by The Duke of Cambridge.Already more than £million has been donated by the public and generous corporations – and the figure is steadily rising.We are “all in this together” but now there is the opportunity for us all to get stuck in and help each other through this crisis.The power of your kindness will help us all get through these dficult days and back to the kind of le that we all want to lead again.To donate to the National Emergencies Trust click here.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brit mum 37 stuck peru coronavirus

The dramatic partial lockdown of Britain came as the coronavirus death toll continues to rise with  more deaths today taking the total to . The Prime Minister told a press conference today that people should stay at home as he warned of the fatal consequences for the communitypeople flouted the new restrictions. So what does the lockdown mean in practice and where can and canapost you go  What is closing and where      The PM ordered all social venues to close their doors today. It means that the following are all expected to close their doors as soon as possible today and not reopen:Food and drink venues Pubs, bars and clubs Cinemas, theatres, concert and bingo halls Spas, indoor leisure and gyms Casinos and betting shops Museums and galleriesThe closures will happen across the UK with the government taking the step with the agreement of the four nations of the UK.  For how long  To start with they will be closed for  days, that is two weeks, but the government has said it will keep the policy under review. Realistically the government believe that the peak of this virus is about three months away and so it is hard to see it ending after the two weeks that they have set out. How will it be enforced     A ban on pubs and restaurants staying open during the coronavirus outbreak will be enforced strictlynecessary through licensing rules, When asked by reporters how the ban would be enforced, he said clearly there are licensing arrangements which will make it relatively simple to do should that really be necessary. He said the ban would be enforced strictly but stopped short of elaborating on measures that could be taken other than possibly indicating that revoking licences may be an option. The licensing system is run through councils and could be a very messy way of enforcing anyone who disobeys. However, emergency laws being rushed through Parliament next week will give the government far stricter and more direct powers to order venues to closethey disobey. Will supermarkets, pharmacies and shops still be open     Yes. Supermarkets will remain open and shops will do too. But the government is advising people to be cautious in these settings, to try and go at a quieter time and to wash their hands. Can I still get a takeaway  Yes, the PM was very clear on this they want restaurants to continue doing takeaway food. In fact, Mr Johnson said he specically wanted restaurants to do this. Earlier this week the government announced it was suspending regulations which mean restaurants have to apply to become takeaways in order to ensure food delivery continued. Why are they doing it now     As coronavirus ramps up around the country - with cases increasing every day - the government said these steps are necessary. Tthe Prime Minister said the measures were needed to reduce unnecessary social gatherings by % in order to have an impact on the infection rate. The speed of our eventual recovery depends entirely on our collective ability to get on top of the virus now and that means we have to take the next steps on scientic advice, he said. And following our plan, we are strengthening the measures announced on Monday. We need now to push down further on that curve of transmission between us. The announcement came after scientists advising the Government warned that restrictions to control the spread of the virus will need to be in place for most of a year - at least. But I have plans to go out this weekend or host a party... Do. Not. Go. Out. Do. Not. Have. People. Over. The government doesnapost plan to personally stop you hosting a party - but it is telling you how irresponsible this is. Healthy people can still carry it and spread it to others. But you can still be a carrier of the disease and pass it on. Mr Johnson said those who flouted the rules could end up causing fatal consequences Can I visit my mum on Motheraposs Day     Boris Johnson said you should think very carefully before paying a Motheraposs Day visit during the coronavirus pandemic. Advice to the public includes avoiding all non-essential contact, a measure which is particularly important for the over-s and others who are most vulnerable to succumb to the infection. Mr Johnson was asked at his Covid- press conference on Friday what his advice was to people thinking about visiting their mother on Sunday. I think my advice would be that people should really think very carefully, irrespectively of whether theyaposre visiting their mother, any elderly person who will be in a vulnerable group, he said. title: coronavirus postponed wedding worry wont
story: NewsopinionCoronavirus has postponed our wedding - and I worry I wont live until new dateMum, author and Mirror columnist Roisin Pelan will need chemotherapy for the rest of her le to treat her incurable cancer, but Covid means she wont be getting married this summerShareCommentsByRoisin Pelan:,  MAR NewsopinionMy sisters upset at the wedding being cancelled really brought it home to me " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe biggest, absolutely worst news I have this week is that our wedding has been postponed. It’s due in July and with so many family members coming from around the world, it’s unlikely that it will be able to go ahead. It’s been such a massive decision but last night, I had a voicemail from my sister who lives in Melbourne and who has battled breast cancer alongside me since my recurrence. . She was absolutely devastated on the phone and it broke my heart into a trillion pieces. She has always been pretty pragmatic and solid as as rock and she has always bloody mothered me. so to hear her sobs was just awful. Our wedding for her is massive and we just can’t do it without her. Our beautul venue, Hobbit Hill, is looking at rescheduling all weddings and so we asked about the possibility of changing our date until July  but all summer dates are booked up. Nooooooooo! We’d really wanted to get married in the summer as the venue has so many gorgeous outdoorsy treats. We were going to be married in the outdoor woodland. Buuuut what can we do  We have changed it to th April and all we can do is hope for some lovely April spring. The devil on my shoulder was there straight away telling me I won’t even be alive to see . Ugh, cancer I hate youI don’t know about anyone , but this has really triggered my cancer anxiety again. Homeschooling Ivy and having her so close to me all the time - it makes me frightened that something bad will happen and she’ll have to be without me. She just couldn’t cope. So many emotions at the moment, stress, worry, fear, anxiety, hope, anger, love. Allll the feels. But anyway, wow - absolute meltdown across the globe. We’re witnessing something we’ve never seen in our letime - toilet roll hoarders, greedy capitalist pigs. It’s bringing out the worst in a lot of us. My brother is stuck in Spain - Ryanair have offered to fly him home for an additional £. My friends ran out of her £. baby formula, but it’s okay because someone is selling them on Ebay for £.!!! These guys in Aldi were allowed to fill their trollies with wipes and nappies last week which they then loaded into their van. You guessed it - Aldi nappies and wipes now on sale on Ebay for a disgusting amount. How the hell is this not illegal  It’s children’s necessities FFS. Ebay have been contacted with no reply, Aldi too. They’re just reaping all the profits from our despair. Do you think the staff will be seeing anything extra in their pay-packet  It is not right. And I’m very happy to say that in contrast - there is so much bloody loveliness coming out of the world too. Facebook groups being set up to help neighbours or vulnerable. I’m social distancing because of chemo and this week, so many people have askedwe need help. I’ve had nappies and hand gel and school books for Ivy delivered - even some flower-seeds to spread in the garden with Ivy. I’ve seen people doing shopping for others and free teaching support being offered and meals being left on doorsteps. I absolutely adore this side of the human race.  I’ve been home-schooling Ivy and although I set out to keep it as ‘schooly’ as I could, I’ve found so many fun activities to do that we both actually enjoy Pizza fractions, writing and then learning all the words to her favourite songs, writing stories and drawing together. We’ve learnt to measure out ingredients on the scales, we’ve learnt about Ireland for St Patrickaposs day and we’ve learnt about bees.There’s so much to learn from once you get going! I’ve been looking here for fun learning games and activities www.brightminds and there’s soooo much!  We’ve also bagged ourselves one of these whoopass Roccbox pizza ovens. OMG I cannot wait to give this a go. They’re portable so you can take them to the beach or the park or wherever you find yourself isolating. And the pizzas only take  seconds to cook - maybe it isn’t the end of the world we’re postponing the wedding because my the forecast for my waistline just got a whole lot bigger! Check them out here.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email A British couple trapped on a cruise ship are terried they are heading into the middle of the coronavirus pandemic after being told their boat was heading towards Italy.Virginia and Bill Maclean are among hundreds of passengers on board the Costa Pacica that have been banned from leaving the ship following the global Covid- outbreak.The couple, from Inverness, Scotland, said they feel abandoned by the UK Foreign Office who they claim have told them there is nothing they can do as the ship set sail for Genoa at around midday yesterday, reports the Daily Record.Virginia, , said she is especially worried about what will happen when they arrive in Italy as husband Bill is , has a pacemaker and is quickly running out of medication. All passengers apart from French nationals were stopped from leaving the ship when it docked in Marseille, France, on Friday morning. The decision reportedly nearly sparked a riot on board, with the coupleaposs fellow passenger Ted Hills, from Lockerbie, revealing fights had broken out between a few people. Virginia said: “We are now really frightened and have real concerns for our safety. Bill along with others only has another week or so of medication left.“Bill has actually just turned  and in Italy, they’re refusing to treat anyone over the age of . They won’t give them any  medical treatment.“I would say about % of the people on this boat are above that age. The Italian health service is just not going to have the capacity to deal with itany of us get sick.” Virginia added that they had received daily confirmation that there is currently no sign of coronavirus on the Costa Pacica. But they’re concerned about the lack of information about what will happen when they arrive in Italy, which now has the highest number of deaths relating to Covid-.  She added: “What we can’t understand is, they’re getting other people back from places like Cuba. I know that they’re so busy at the moment. “If they weren’t taking us to Italy and we were staying here in Marseille, I could understand it but they’re taking us to Italy which is the eye of the storm. “If we had information we could deal with it whether it was good, bad or ugly but they’re not giving us any information. “My husband and I tried to speak to the captain this morning and asked what would happen when we got to Italy and he just threw his hands up in the air and walked away from us. “We asked whatwe get to Italy and we can’t get off the boat because it’s dangerous, and he said well you can just stay on the boat for two months and turned around and walked away.  “We’re trying to get someone in the UK government to intervene and to stop the boat from leaving here. They just can’t send us to Italy.” The couple boarded the boat in Buenos Aires on March  before setting sail to Brazil. It was then due to travel to Tenere but was redirected to Barcelona with passengers told they could disembark. Spanish authorities then implemented a country-wide shutdown and the boat headed to Marseille, where again, travellers were told they would be able to leave. Virginia said: “The boat really shouldn’t have come to Europe, but they kept charging on with it and we were at sea for  days.  “They told us we would be getting off in Barcelona but that closed. They then told us we would be getting off yesterday here in Marseille. “They asked for all our onward flight details, they even explained they would put an ‘air bridge’ in place to get us off the boat and onto sanitised shuttle buses to the airport and put us onto planes that they wouldn’t fill so we wouldn’t get infected by coronavirus. “They told me they had chartered flights to Heathrow and Gatwick so everyone was ready to get off. “When we came to Marseille yesterday, there was actually a sense of jubilation at seeing and after  days. But at pm, the captain said it was only French nationals that would be getting off.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailAstonishing images show hundreds of shoppers queueing around a Tesco car park at am in a bid to purchase lockdown supplies. This is despite officials stressing there is no need to panic buy or stockpile - and that it means those most in need cannot get their essentials. The queue stretched the entireof the Tesco car park in New Malden, south-west London this morning. Drone footage taken at am shows shoppers patiently waiting in line for the superstore to open. The queue is so long some shoppers are waiting near to the entrance and exit of the car park on the roadside. And in another Tesco Extra in Hampton, Peterborough, shelves had already cleared by am this morning. It comes after Tesco announced a three per person limit on all items as part of latest efforts to curb panic-buying. The restrictions were imposed on Thursday but at this stage has done little to cope with the high demand. Many shoppers visiting supermarkets in the afternoon or evening have been greeted with empty shelves, with most meat, including chicken, turkey and beef sold out. Items such as frozen vegetables, crisps, squash, fresh milk, pasta and rice are also proving hard to get hold of, as are most tinned foods, such as pasta sauces.  Overnight three people were arrested in the Essex area for a suspected theft of toilet roll. Police were called to the Tesco superstore in New Malden on Friday after tensions among shoppers increased, with many ransacking shelves and paying little attention to pensioners. In a letter to staff, Tesco chief executive Dave Lewis wrote that all counter services will be closed to focus on stocking shelves from Thursday.  Lewis said the chain will encourage healthy shoppers to come to stores and free up online capacity, and make am to am an hour prioritised to vulnerable and elderly customers. He added: It is fair to say that we find ourselves in uncharted waters. Covid- is bringing a change to the UK and itaposs clear that lots of things are going to have to sht around in order to help us cope.  A Tesco spokesperson added: ​We are changing these store hours to ensure we can serve customers better at this time.  It gives our colleagues the time overnight to restock the store, replenish the shelves and support our online grocery service at a time when demand is high. In a bid to cope with demand, Tesco is advertising thousands of jobs as the stockpiling shows little sign of slowing down.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA mum left gasping for air due to suspected coronavirus has been left heartbroken because she wonapost see her daughter for at least two weeks. Ingé Kirsten, from Newcastle, posted harrowing video showing her coughing while hooked up to a ventilator with a mask over her face in hospital. In another clip, the -year-old, who has a heart condition, repeatedly coughs and struggles to breathe as she begs people to self-isolate and follow social distancing guidelines. She hit out at those who are ignoring the governmentaposs Covid- advice, telling : I think it’s really bad. I don’t think people have realised how serious it is. Iaposm sure no one would want themselves or their loved ones in this position or worse. Have you been affected by the coronavirus outbreak  Email webnews@mirror. Why aren’t pubs or bars realising the impact that they are having by staying open  Why would people put their lives and others at risk  It’s bizarre to me. I think people think they’re immune to it. No one is. It’s doesn’t discriminate who it takes hold of. “And I understand people are scared and panicking buying but not sparing a thought for other is awful. I’m glad I can’t leave my house to witness it first hand. People have been leaving care packages at my door for me.I’ve seen so many lovely posts of people helping others, older people, with care packages. I shared my story as I was sick of people not taking it seriously and still putting themselves or others at risk. Hopefully they’ll be a bit more mindful now. Ingé, who works in a call centre, said doctors told her that she is likely suffering from coronavirus. She was sent home without being tested and told to stay away from others. Her -year-old daughter, Macey, and her cousin have been ordered to self-isolate away from her due to potential exposure to Covid- Ingé said: It started last Thursday, I think. The day after my birthday. I didn’t do anything on my birthday as I’ve just moved into my new house. But I slept for almost  hours and just generally felt really unwell.Then sat I started to get a sore throat and losing my voice. By Sunday afternoon I could barely breathe for coughing. I had to call  again last night and they sent an ambulance pretty quick as I couldn’t breathe for coughing. They ran some tests for blood pressure, temperature, etc but as it wasn’t bad enough to be admitted they’ve told me to carry on as I am isolating at home with the steroids and paracetamol.  Ingé desperately misses her daughter and has been trying to cope with loneliness while self-isolating. She said: It is really hard being away from Macey. She came to hospital with me and my cousin and the doctor told her to take my daughter home to her house as she cannot be around me for  days. So she’s currently at my cousinaposs home. We’ve been FaceTiming but she’s only  and missing being with me a lot.  In one of her videos, Ingé coughs repeatedly and struggles to breathe. She wheezes with every breath and holds her hand to her chest as she coughs in pain. She tells the camera: I just wanted to make a video of how bad it actually is because I know a lot of people out there donapost really believe that itaposs a serious virus or anything like that. This is me breathing. The most common symptoms of the coronavirus are: a dry, persistent cougha feverIf you experience these symptoms, you should immediately self-isolate yourself for seven days. It is not necessary to call NHS  unless your symptoms get more severe. Some patients have reported fatigue, headaches, shortness of breath and aches and pains. Sneezing is not a symptom of the coronavirus. Itaposs absolutely horrendous so any advice to those who donapost believe it or arenapost taking any safety precautions, seriously do. None of this is worth your health. In a post, she wrote: I realise that this is all a very worrying time and some people are not that concerned. I didn’t want to share my experience so publicly however people should know that this virus disease is no laughing matter. It began last week without me even realising I may have been infected. Thursday I slept for almost  hours, Saturday I started with a sore throat and began to lose my voice. For those concerned they have coronavirus in the UK, Public Health England has issued advice about how to self-isolate. . Stay at home: Donapost leave your house except when you need to seek medical care. Ask for help buying groceries or have them delivered.. Stat away from your housemates: Stick in a well-ventilated room away from others, with the door closed. Use a separate bathroom and wear a facemask when it shared areas.. Call ahead before visiting the doctors so they can take extra precautionary measures.. Cover you coughs and sneezes: Make sure to cover your nose and mouth and to throw away disposable tissues in a plastic waste bag.. Wash your hands regularly: This should be done often and thoroughly with soap and water, for at least  seconds, rinse and dry thoroughly.. Avoid sharing household items: You should not share dishes, drinking glasses, cups, eating utensils, towels, bedding or other items with other people in your home when you have used them. After using these items, wash them thoroughly with soap and water.. Do not have visitors in your home. . Keep away from your petspossible.. Keep your clothes clean: Do laundry on the highest temperature possible and clean all surfaces around the washing machine.. Monitor your symptoms: Seek prompt medical attentionyour illness is worsening, for example,you have dficulty breathing, orthe person you are caring for symptoms are worsening.

story: NewsCoronavirus: New supermarket opening times - and all the latest panic buying rulesAsda, Aldi, Tesco, MS, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Iceland have changed their opening hours and rules in response to the coronavirus outbreak, which sparked panic buyingShareCommentsByRachel PughMatthew Dresch:,  MAR Updated:,  MAR NewsBritains major supermarkets have unveiled their new opening hours in response to the outbreak " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Supermarkets have released their new opening times in response to the coronavirus outbreak.Panic buying has left many shops short of stock, forcing the Government to loosen restrictions on supermarkets to ensure essential goods are available. All of the major supermarkets, including Asda, Aldi, Tesco, MS, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Iceland, have now changed their opening hours. They have also introduced new rules to keep both stores and shoppers safe.Today Sainsbury’s announced that it will be taking further action to make sure supermarkets are ing to their best possible ability, the Manchester Evening News reports.Changes to opening hours Sainsbury’s Sainsbury’s has now updated its extended opening times and store rules. In a letter to customers, the supermarket’s CEO Mike Coupe said: “You will have seen that we put restrictions in place this week to ensure that more products are on shelf for longer. From Monday rd March, we are consolidating our opening hours and all our supermarkets will be open from am to pm, Monday-Saturday, including those with an Argos store. Sunday opening, Sainsbury’s Local and petrol station opening times will stay the same.” Every Monday, Wednesday and Friday, all our supermarkets will dedicate am - am to serving elderly, disabled and vulnerable customers, as well as NHS and Social Care workers.To find the opening hours for your local store, visit  www.stores.sainsburys Asda Asda will be temporarily closing its  hour stores between am and am.To check opening hours for your local store, visit  www.storelocator.asda. TescoA number of stores are now operating at reduced hours due to operational reasons, Tesco said on Twitter after photos showed shelves cleared of food and other essential goods.Some Tesco Extra stores and largerstores have reduced their hours to between am and pm so they can properly restock overnight. TomorrowTesco will be offering priority browsing to NHS workers an hour before stores open. It will not apply to Express stores.Find your  nearest Tesco shop here Aldi Aldi’s opening hours are am to pm from Monday to Saturday, and am to pm on Sundays.To check your local store, visit  www.aldi.  Morrisons Opening hours y across the country. To find the opening hours for your local Morrisons store, visit www.groceries.morrisons. Iceland Iceland will open its supermarkets early for elderly customers to visit before stores open to the public. Each day, elderly shoppers can visit between am - am to get their shopping first.To check opening times at your local store, visit  www.iceland.  Restrictions on certain items Sainsbury’s Today, Sainsbury’s announced that it was taking further action to ensure there’s enough products to go round, and has put restrictions on a number of products, so customers can now buy a maximum of three any grocery product and a maximum of two of the most popular items including toilet paper, soap and UHT milk. Tesco Tesco has put restrictions on certain products including anti-bacterial wipes, dried pasta and toilet roll. Products are now limited to two per customer. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSupermarket bosses are facing growing calls to create exclusive shopping hours for struggling NHS staff as selfish panic-buyers ­continue to pick shelves clean. Tesco and Marks  Spencer unveiled dedicated slots after a heartbreaking video by critical care nurse Dawn Bilbrough begged hoarders to be considerate. And her plea has been backed by the Royal College of Nursing, the Royal College of Physicians and union Unison, which are telling supermarkets and the Government: “More must be done.” Dawn, , who works in an intensive care unit in Leeds, West Yorks, was tearful as she told of finding aisles of empty racking as she tried to buy a few items after a two-day sht. While she was saving lives, coronavirus fears fuelled scenes of chaos across the land with people queueing outside supermarkets and cash and carries from the early hours to stockpile. In an emotional appeal that shamed the culprits, Dawn said: “I’ve just come out of the supermarket – there’s no fruit and veg. “I had a little cry in there. I’m a critical care nurse and I’ve just finished  hours of work and I just wanted to get some stuff in for the next  hours. I just don’t know how I’m supposed to stay healthy. “Those people who are just stripping the shelves of basic foods – you need to stop it because it’s people like me that are going to be looking after you when you are at your lowest. Just stop it. Please.” Tesco has now said the hour before official opening every Sunday will be a shopping slot exclusively for NHS staff, with ID checks to keep out hoarders.  The firm said: “We know those working for the NHS may be finding it hard to find time to shop at the moment. “So from this Sunday we’re going to introduce a special hour for NHS staff as a thank you for all they are doing. All we ask is they bring ID. We will be asking all other customers to be respectful and to shop in the usual hours.” MS is setting aside its first hour on Tuesdays and Fridays “for our brilliant NHS and emergency workers”. The chain will also be asking for ID to stop stockpilers. Speaking yesterday on ITV’s This Morning Dawn, from York, said she was “overwhelmed” by the response to her plea. She said: “I understand the fear but we are not a Third World country. People need to have a bit of awareness and remember other people actually need to survive this virus.”  Health Secretary Matt Hancock, who has repeatedly tried to assure the nation there is no shops supply crisis, said: “I stand with Dawn. I think she has put it better than anybody  could. It’s vital that people act responsibly.” But the message continued to fall on deaf ears as thousands carried on stockpiling. Yesterday, we revealed how stunned shoppers branded panic-buyers “locusts” after shelves were stripped bare, sometimes in  minutes. And we told of how staff were abused over queues and purchase restrictions – while there were even reports of shoppers fighting and attacking workers. The Royal College of Nursing and Royal College of Physicians have now urged  major chains to create priority shopping times for all frontline workers. In an open letter referencing Dawn’s video, the RCN said: “Sadly, her experience is far from unique.  “Health and care professionals are faced with empty shelves. Our frontline staff ensure the health and wellbeing of our country and we must do all that we can to support them in their efforts.” Union Unison welcomed the move to help NHS staff. But chief Dave Prentis said: “The time has come for ministers to take more decisive action to avoid key workers and vulnerable people being without food. While some supermarkets must be praised for setting aside time, the initiative is patchy and doesn’t account for sht patterns. More must be done.” According to trade magazine The Grocer, we splurged £million on essentials in the first week of March – compared with £.million last year.  Profiteering off pandemic panic Shops, online retailers and eBay sellers are accused of profiteering from essentials such as toilet paper, baby milk and hand sanitiser. Some shoppers have been spotted buying vast quantities of key items, leading to fears they plan to exploit shortages to make quick profits online. One eBay seller is offering an g tub of Aptamil baby formula milk for £, when it normally retails for around £. They are also selling an “NHS-approved” ml bottle of hand sanitiser for £.. One eBay user posted: “Vile bulk buyer bumping up prices during a pandemic.” Another is selling an g tub of Cow  Gate follow-on milk for £.. One shopper said: “What kind of human being does this at a time when everyone needs to band together ” Another said: “You try to make a profit when some people can’t feed their babies.”
