title: call-support-help-young-asylum-seekers
story: The under-s, all described as ldquospontaneous arrivals, sought help in the county after escaping traumatic experiences and required a range of care services.However, a meeting of East Lothian Councilrsquos cabinet was told that the Home Office grant for caring for youngsters came nowhere near covering the costs.Chief social worker Judith Tait said that the cost to the council of providing housing support for the five young people between August  and December  had been pound, ndash to date the Home Office has reimbursed the local authority pound,.She said the Home Office offered pound a day for young people who arrive outwith its formal resettlement schemes and pound. for over-s who are placed in bed and breakfast or supported accommodation.ldquoThe funding available is not enough to met the needs ndash it is not meeting the range of services needed, said the chief social worker.ldquoIn the case of over-s, the pound. payment is not fit for purpose.Cabinet members were told that since August , five refugees had arrived in East Lothian ndash all under  and all having arrived in the county through unofficial means.And they were told that while Home Office funding was for housing support, it did not cover the staffing requirements for the youngsters who have intensive needs.They were told one of the teenagers who arrived had lost their entire home before being trafficked.Emma Clater, acting childrenrsquos services manager with the council, told them: ldquoThis young person had seen both their parents killed and their entire village wiped out before being passed through a succession of aunts and uncles and eventually being trafficked.ldquoThey were living in a house with other trafficked young people forced to work on a cannabis farm when they escaped.She added of young refugees: ldquoOften they arrive at a house, police station or service station in inappropriate dress for the weather and with very little language skills, which alerts the authorities. They are extremely traumatised by their experiences and need a range of support.Councillor Willie Innes, council leader, called for more to be done by the Home Office to meet the costs of supporting refugees. He said that leaving local authorities to pick up the bill could create ision in communities.Mr Innes said: ldquoIt creates a sense of animosity between people native to the area and people coming in who seem to be benefiting at their expense.And he highlighted the local authorityrsquos history of providing homes for refugees, both as part of the recent Syrian re-homing programme and previous projects to home Bosnian refugees.He said: ldquoWe have a proud history of stepping up to the mark when called on to do so in East Lothian.ldquoThese people come with huge trauma and it is important they are treated with the dignity and respect they deserve.A Home Office spokesperson said it had increased payment for local authorities for all children regardless of their age to pound and the UK had provided protection for more than , vulnerable children since .They said: ldquoThe UK has a proud history of welcoming and supporting those in need of our protection, and we are grateful to local authorities across the country who are supporting vulnerable young asylum seekers.ldquoThe Home Office provides a contribution to the costs incurred by local authorities in looking after unaccompanied asylum-seeking childrenand former UASC care leavers. In May , we announced a signicant increase in the funding of their UASC support costs.East Lothian Council has provided homes for about  families ndash  refugees ndash from Syria since pledging to support up to seven families a year as part of a UK-wide scheme introduced five years ago.In the early s, the local authority helped resettle Bosnian refugees in the county, as well as Kosovan refugees later that decade.The cabinet was asked to support the local authority being part of a new global resettlement scheme which is being launched by the UK Government to replace the scheme next month and will widen the areas where refugees can come from.Members of the cabinet gave the move their backing.

title: tims-tales-everyone-not-anyone
story: IT WAS a beautul apple tree. Every year, as the summer faded into autumn, it gave its gt of apples to anyone who happened to pass. Children from the local village who were always hungry would sit under it and eat ripe apples until they had tummy ache. Old folk would come and collect the apples to make pies, sauces and chutney.When the apples from the lower branches had been eaten, the children would climb and pick the ones higher up. It was a game to catch them and put them in a basket.There were so many apples that the older children had to carry the heavy baskets down to the village and shared the apples with everyone.The tree gave so many apples that everyone in the village had as many as they could eat or use. There were always plenty left over on the ground for the animals and insects who also feasted on the fallen ripe fruit. Thankfully nobody owned the tree, it had seeded itself many years ago on the verge of the road that led to the village.Then one year, a traveller arrived just as the apple tree was beginning to bear fruit. He sat under the tree and admired the beauty of it. The apples were ripening in the sun and one of them fell by his feet. He picked it up and ate it. It was crisp and sweet and really delicious.A group of children arrived from the village. ldquoHello mister, they said with a smile, ldquowersquove come to pick apples. They set about picking the most reachable ripe apples, while of course eating some of them in the process.ldquoWhat delicious apples, I must tell my we and children about them, said the traveller as he set off along the road.ldquoHere, said one of the children, holding out a handful of apples. ldquoThese are really ripe, give them to your family. We have more than enough to carry.The traveller smiled. ldquoHow kind, he said. He put them in his pockets and went on his way.But that evening, the child who had given the apples to the traveller was chastised by her parents. ldquoWhy did you do that  Now that man will come back with his family and take our apples.ldquoBut the tree gives us more apples than we can eat, the girl said, ldquosurely a few can be shared with people outside the village. Besides, the tree is by the side of the road, arenrsquot the apples for everyone, thatrsquos what yoursquove always said ldquoYes, they are for everyone, her father replied, ldquobut not just for anyone.His daughter was confused by this answer she didnrsquot understand what it meant. However, it seemed such a small and unimportant issue that she said nothing more of it. She knew that there would be more than enough apples for everyone, and even anyone.A few days later, when the girlrsquos grandmother went to collect ripe apples for a pie, she met the stranger with his we and two children. They had a small basket full of apples. The family were friendly and greeted the grandmother, but she ed a forced smile. She quickly collected her apples and rushed home.She told about the strangerrsquos family collecting the apples and the girlrsquos father was angry.ldquoSee, he said to his daughter, ldquoI told you they were not for just anyone. Now there will be none left for everyone .But his daughter was still confused. There were always many hundreds of apples. ldquoYou are young and donrsquot understand, he said. ldquoTomorrow we will get up early and make sure we can collect our share of the apples.The following day the family were up at the crack of dawn. They took all the baskets they could and went to the apple tree. Their neighbours peered out of the window, wondering what the family were doing.Then they saw them at the apple tree, filling many baskets of ripe apples. Later in the morning, some children from the village joined them.One of them went to pick up an apple that had just fallen. But the grandmother rushed and snatched it first and put it in her basket. So the child just smiled and gently shook a branch and another fell.When the familyrsquos baskets were full, they carried them back to the house. But it took them three trips, and the father left his daughter to guard the full baskets while he and the rest of the family carried as much they could.ldquoWhy are you collecting so many apples at once  asked one of her friends.The young girl nibbled her lip and looked at the ground. ldquoDonrsquot know really. My father says Irsquom too young to understand, but he says the apples are for everyone but not just anyone.ldquoWhorsquos anyone then She looked up and shook her head: ldquoNot sure, but anyone is taking our apples so we have to get them first.When the children of the village ed home with their apples, they told their parents what had happened.ldquoAnyone is taking our apples, so there will not be enough for everyone.The next day, more families got up early and set off for the apple tree.This time, the apple picking was very dferent to the way it had always been. In the past, people would pick the apples with each other, because everyone knew there was enough to go round. This time they were picking them for themselves.Fights started and people began to pull apples that were not ripe. So many people climbed onto the branches to get the apples that the tree started to creak.Soon, not a single apple remained on the tree. For the first time ever, there were none left for the animals or insects. Some peoplersquos homes were so full of apples that they hardly had room to move inside the house.Other people, who were not quick enough, had no apples at all. Some of these were people who really needed the apples. But those who had many wouldnrsquot share them for fear that anyone would get them.The houses of the people who collected more apples than they needed became full of fruit flies and other insects as their piles of apples began to rot.But the next year, everyone was ready. They had made big baskets and were determined not to miss out. But when they arrived at the tree it was surrounded by a hastily built wall with a guard at the gate.ldquoWho has done this  they cried.It was the king. He had heard of the apple tree and how crisp and sweet the apples were, so much so that people would fight and hoard the fruit. So, as the richest and most powerful man in the kingdom, he decided he would make sure the apples graced his table.ldquoBut there are more apples than the king can eat! protested the people.ldquoIndeed, said the guard ldquoand the King is generous. He will sell you the apples he does not need.ldquoSell them  But the apples have always been free for everyone!ldquoNot any more, said the guard.The young girl went up to her father. ldquoNow I understand, she said, ldquoanyone is the king.

title: coronavirus-gp-practices-east-lothian-introduce-new-measures

check in service -people now have to check in with a receptionist.It has also launched a new online prescription ordering service, those not registered can visit northberwickhealthcentre.scot.nhs.uk news,.htm, download a form, fill it in and hand it in.Lammermuir Medical Practice has also disabled its online appointment service.Tranent Medical Practice has made its surgery pod, a self-service device that allows patients to get their weight and blood pressure checked, unavailable for use.Those with routine appointments at Harbours Medical Practice in Cockenzie are asked to phone the practice, pressing option two, as it is making changes to its routine appointment system.It has also asked that people with symptoms, those who have had contact with an infected person or those who have been in an affected place to not enter any of its buildings.Prestonpans Group Practice has also given this advice and asked that evenpeople have mild symptoms they should not visit the surgery.Meanwhile, Orchard Medical Practice in Haddington is asking all patients not to attend the practice but instead to phone to request an appointment. Anyone then deemed to required a face-to-face appointment will be asked screening questions.All pre-existing appointments are being reviewed and some may be cancelled and re-scheduled.Prescriptions will also not be able to be picked up from the surgery and instead arrangements will be made for them to be picked up at a pharmacy.Full details of these measures are on Orchard Medical Practices website.Riverside Medical Practice in Musselburgh said: "Riverside Medical Practice is taking action in response to the coronavirus outbreak. We are following current national guidance."We are suspending all routine face-to-face appointments. If you have an appointment booked please contact the reception team and we will re-arrange your booking to a telephone appointment. Our staff will also be trying to get in touch with these patients shortly by phone."Riverside will continue to give advice and see patients where medically necessary. All appointments are now made by phone assessment according to medical prioritisation and need.Thank you for your understanding."For more information on coronavirus, visit nhsinform.scot coronavirusFor the latest information on the situation at your GP practice, check the practice website.

title: musselburgh-explore-closed-doors-race-meeting
story: The East Lothian course is scheduled to stage the Racing Post Go North meeting on Fridaybut the Scottish Government announced on Thursday that events of more than  people should not take place in light of the coronavirus outbreak.It is possible Musselburgh will follow Kelso Racecourses lead, which has opted to stage its meeting on Monday behind closed doors.Musselburgh is consulting with the Britsh Horseracing Authorityand other relevant stakeholders to establish how it can continue to support the racing industry in a manner which would be contrary to the Scottish Government ruling.Bill Farnsworth, Musselburgh Racecourse General Manager, said: "We will follow the guidelines issued by the Scottish Government and explore all options available to us to establishwe can continue racing during this exceptional time."The Racing Post Go North meeting has more than pound, in prizemoney and is a very important fixture for Scottish trainers and stables across the north of England."The racing industry, the owners, the trainers and stable staff, need all the support they can get and it is incumbent on us to continue racingpossible, which helps maintain jobs and incomes."It is hoped other fixtures scheduled for March  and on Easter Saturday will go ahead, but the racecourse will review the situation on a regular basis and strictly follow all government and NHS advice on best practice on containing the virus."In the weeks leading up to future meetings, we will review the situation on a daily basis, always following expert advice on how we can play our part in mitigating the spread of COVID-."We will provide regular updates on our website and social media channels, to advise racegoers, owners and trainers on anypotential changes to our scheduled race meetings."For more information, go to www.musselburgh-racecourse

story: enjoyleisure is in charge of a range of sports facilities across the county, including the Aubigny Sports Centre in Haddington.A spokeswoman for enjoyleisure said: "We would like to confirm that all our facilities are currently open, and all our class and coach activity programmes are going ahead as scheduled."If you are a member of a club organisation that utilises enjoyleisure facilities, please contact your club representatives for updates."We are closely monitoring the current situation regarding the coronavirus , and are following guidance from the government and public health authorities."We have additional cleaning schedules in place, and we ask that all customers follow the precautionary measures advised by NHS."For further information please visit, www.nhs.uk conditions coronavirus-covid-"

title: coronavirus-classes-queen-margaret-university-postponed-next-week
story: The university, near Musselburgh, outlined their stance yesterdayand vowed to keep students and staff updated of any future developments.Dr Richard Butt, deputy principal, said: "Queen Margaret University is continuing to monitor closely and follow healthcare and Government advice from Health Protection Scotland."Our campus and halls of residence remain open. We will comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and the Scottish Government and take any necessary stepswe are advised to do so in the future."The guidance on the website will be updated,required, by pm each day."Learning and teaching will move entirely online by next Monday .Dr Butt added: "We will be moving to delivering teaching online."Reduced face-to-face teaching will begin from Monday , and no face-to face teaching will take place from March  until further notice."If there are any changes to your classes in the week beginning March , information will be published on the Hub."Academic staff will decide how best to conduct teaching and learning activities, using a range of resources to best support students."Meanwhile, all undergraduate and taught postgraduate exams and assessments scheduled for next Monday, including those for the Semester  exam period , and reassessments scheduled for the end of July, will be delivered online or by other methods of alternate assessment.Assessment type will be guided by academic discipline and academic staff expertise.Students will be notied as early as possible about what online assessments mean in practice.Inidual Learning Plan Adjustments will also continue.Students wishing tohome can do so.Dr Butt added: "We understand that some students, particularly those from overseas, may be anxious and you may be considering ing home."If you do decide tohome, you will not be penalised for doing so."Whilst we are changing our mode of learning and teaching and taking measures to be responsive to an evolving situation, QMUrsquos campus will remain open."We have had no indication from Health Protection Scotland or the Scottish Government that we should close, and buildings, services and facilities will run as usual.Staff and students can be on campus and our library, specialist facilities, student services, refectory, the halls of residences and Studentsrsquo Union are also open."We will continue to monitor and comply with advice from Health Protection Scotland and take any necessary steps, including possible campus closure,we are advised to do so in the future. "Graduation ceremonies scheduled for July will also be rescheduled, most likely to autumn.

title: bbc-delays-end-free-tv-licence-over-75s-august-due-coronavirus
story: A joint statement said: "The BBC and the Government have been discussing the national coronavirus situation."Changes to the TV licence for people aged over  had been due to come into effect on June ."But during this time we do not want anyone to be worried about any potential change."The BBCs priority over the coming period will be to do everything we can to serve the nation at this uniquely challenging time."As the national broadcaster, the BBC has a vital role to play in supplying information to the public in the weeks and months ahead."Recognising the exceptional circumstances, the BBC Board has therefore decided to change the start date of the new policy."Our current plan is to now bring it into place on August . We will of course keep the issue under review as the situation continues to evolve."Chairman of the BBC, Sir David Clementi, added: "The BBC board has decided to delay changes to over s licence fees."We are in exceptional circumstances. Now is not the right time. We are fully focussed on delivering our services to the public at this dficult time."What has the reaction been Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said: "I am pleased the BBC has worked with us and agreed to delay their licence fee changes for over-s from coming in and will keep this under review."It will be welcome news to millions of older people who now dont need to worry about their TV licence during this challenging period."It is right that the BBC have recognised the exceptional circumstances posed by the coronavirus outbreak and the need for the whole country to pull together in the national effort."

title: coronavirus-musselburgh-racecourse-hold-meetings-behind-closed-doors
story: This weekrsquos Racing Post Go North race day will be open only to racing connections and will be in line with the Scottish Government recommendation that no events of more than  people should be held in light of the coronavirusoutbreak.Those attending will be asked to sign a self-declaration form that they do not have a temperature or symptoms associated with coronavirus. Anyone who has pre-booked tickets for either March race day will receive a full refund.Musselburgh Racecourse general manager Bill Farnsworth said: "Behind closed doors racing will comply with the guidelines set out by the Scottish Government and a meeting of less than  people, which includes participants, connections and staff, will not add any additional stress to emergency services."The racing industry, like many other sectors, is facing unprecedented challenges and is fighting for its future. We are keen to do whatever we can to support jobs and to mitigate loss of income, and holding meetings behind closed doors seems a sensible approach."Racingrsquos governing body the British Horseracing Authorityearlier announced all racing in Scotland, England and Wales would take place without spectators and with attendance limits until March .Nick Rust, chief executive of the BHA, said: "Racecourses and racing yards are embedded in their local communities and we are acutely aware of our responsibilities to protect public health."The restrictions we are putting in place to close racing to spectators and limit attendees will reduce demand on public services. We also have a range of measures in place designed in response to the Governmentrsquos guidance on public health and we will continue to update these as appropriate."Musselburgh will review how racing may proceed for its popular Betway Easter Saturday Race Day on April  as the situation develops and will continue to follow all Government and NHS advice on best practice on containing the virus.Regular updates on the racecourse website and social media channels,will advise racegoers, owners and trainers on any material changes to scheduled race meetings.For more information, visit musselburgh-racecourse

title: coronavirus-edinburgh-marathon-festival-rescheduled-september
story: The event, much of which takes place in East Lothian, had been due to take place in May but has now been postponed until the autumn as events across the country are called off in a bid to stop the spread of the disease.A statement from the organisers on the events website said: "We have been working closely with the local authorities in Edinburgh and East Lothian, the emergency service teams and our other delivery partners, and are delighted to confirm that the Edinburgh Marathon Festival will take place on Saturday th and Sunday th September, ."Neil Kilgour, Edinburgh Marathon Festival race director, said:ldquoWe are grateful that an alternative date has been secured for the event and we want to thank those who have been part of making this happen.ldquoWe know how important the event is for our affiliate charities and those who have been committed to training through the winter months to put themselves on the start line."The Edinburgh Marathon Festival is a beacon of positivity, at a time when it is needed most. It gives people the opportunity to focus on what comes beyond the concerns and uncertainty of the coming weeks, to know that it will pass, and that they still have the opportunity to achieve something truly great ndash  does not need to be defined by the virus, it can remain defined by our participants as a year of personal triumph.The website statement continued: "The importance of selecting a date that would allow participants an appropriate timeline to successfully alter their training programme and travel itinerary, has been paramount."We sincerely hope that all our current participants will be able to join us on September  and however,that is not possible, we have extended the entry transfer period until pm on Friday, July ."Entries for the  event have now re-opened and will remain open untilnoon on Friday, May , or until they reach capacity, whichever comes first. At this point, entries for the May  event will become available."We would like to thank our participants for their understanding and patience over the past few days, to encourage everyone to continue following the advice given by the World Health Organisation to prevent the wider spread of the virus, and to continue making sensible decisions to keep others safe during this time."

title: pandemic---last-ones-coronavirus
story: In a statement,Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus, the WHO chief, said:"We have called every day for countries to take urgent and aggressive action. We have rung the alarm bell loud and clear."All countries can still change the course of this pandemic. If countries detect, test, treat, isolate, trace and mobilise their people in the response," he said.A viral outbreak could be categorised as a pandemicit is markedly dferent from recently circulating strains, andhumans have little or no immunity to it, according to the UKrsquosHealth and Safety Executive.When was the last pandemic Before we get to what the last pandemic was, you may be surprised to know that there is actually a pandemic other than coronavirus ongoing right now.AIDS is currently classed as a pandemic by the WHO, with infection rates as high as  per cent in southern and eastern Africa.In , the HIV prevalence rate among pregnant women in South Africa was  per cent.Effective education about safer sexual practices and blood-borne infection precautions training have helped to slow down infection rates, but the diseases status remains.Before coronavirus, the last pandemic to grip the world was that of the  flu pandemic, more commonly known as swine flu.It is estimated that  to  per cent of the global population contracted swine flu, though the fatality rate was relatively low, at about . to . per cent.Between , and , people were thought to have died.Previous pandemics in historyPandemics are nothing new, and even before the mass transit of the worlds population through air travel, poor hygiene technologies in even developed countries led to mass outbreaks of disease.Cholera is one such disease, which has seen multiple pandemics throughout history. The first began in  on the Indian subcontinent, spreading across India by , and claiming the lives of , British troops stationed there.Choleras outbreak have mainly kept to the Indian subcontinent , although there have been pandemics in both Europe and North America.Spanish flu is perhaps the deadliest pandemic in relatively recent history. From  to  it infected  million people around the world, including people on remote Pacic islands and in the Arctic. to  million people are thought to have died from the strain - thats more people than were killed in World War I. Ithad an unusually high mortality rate for young adults.Of course, the most famous pandemic is that of the Black Plague, which between  and  killed an estimated  million people.Coronavirus: the factsWhat is coronavirus What caused coronavirus How is it spread What are the symptoms What precautions can be taken What should I doI feel unwell When to call NHS

title: aldi-boss-issues-plea-customers-no-need-coronavirus-panic-buying
story: In a letter published on the supermarket chains social media pages on Monday, he said: "As you will be aware, all supermarkets have been working very hard to keep up with demand over the last few days."I am writing to reassure you, and all our other valued customers, that our colleagues and trusted suppliers are working round the clock to keep our warehouses fully stocked."We have increased orders from our suppliers and our warehouses have sufficient stock to replenish all stores."This includes all of the essentials such as sanitary and baby products."Our amazing colleagues have been working tirelessly to restock our stores."However, unprecedented demand for certain products has made it dficult for us to ensure that there are no gaps on shelves."All of our stores receive daily deliveries, often multiple times a day."Soa certain product is not available when you visit, it will be replenished in the overwhelming majority of cases by the following day."We have taken action to discourage people buying more than they need."Customers are currently limited to buying four items of any one product during each visit."This is still signicantly more than most customers would buy in a normal shopping trip and we hope this temporary restriction will give as many customers as possible the opportunity to get what they need, every time they visit."Irsquom sure, like me, you are also concerned about those who are vulnerable at this time."Not everyone has the financial or practical resources to buy in bulk, including our elderly customers."We all have a responsibility to ensure we only buy what we and our families need. If we shop as we normally do, our stores will quicklyto normal."Finally, my sincere thanks to you for your continued support and to every single one of our colleagues."Itrsquos the people at Aldi that make our business special and they have come together like never before to serve you, our customers, during this extremely busy time."Coronavirus: the factsWhat is coronavirus What caused coronavirus How is it spread What are the symptoms What precautions can be taken What is theGovernment saying Should I avoid public places What should I doI feel unwell When to call NHS

title: coronavirus-emergency-plans-approved-east-lothian-council
story: Councillors have agreed to allow the local authorityrsquos chief executive Monica Pattersonto introduce emergency recess measures when she believes it becomes necessary as the coronavirusspreads.It will mean a cross-party group featuring the leaders of the councilrsquos three parties or their deputies will take decisions behind closed doors alongside the chief executive and officers required, as well as cabinet spokespersons.Depute council leader Norman Hampshire said that councillors faced an ldquoextremely serious situation.He said: ldquoIt is vital all councillors pull together and take the dficult decisions we need to make to deal with this situation.ldquoIt is important that the message going out is in line with the national message and we do not deviate.SNP Group leader Stuart Currie seconded the comments by Mr Hampshire, saying this was not the time for politics to play a part in decisions.Mr Currie said: ldquoWhat we are seeing across East Lothian is the voluntary sector, communities and area partnerships, everyone talking about how they can assist and help and that is really important.ldquoIt is important we can continue to make decisions ndash there is a time for politics but it ainrsquot now.The local authority has issued guidance to staff to follow national guidelines and stay home and self-isolate for seven daysthey have any mild symptoms of the coronavirus.Managers are being asked to cancel non-essential meetings, particularly ones which involve a high number of people, and vehicles and keyboards used by more than one person are beingsupplied with wipes.Among the advice issued to staff by the council is not to leave food out uncovered and to avoid ldquotouching of surfaces and avoid putting things like phones, pens or laptops down on surfaces unless you know they have been recently cleaned, particularly on home visits.They are also being advised: ldquoWhere possible sit a distance of a couple of metres from clients other staff.The local authority has also written to parents advising that all additional school activities, including after-school clubs and trips, have been cancelled alongside any shows or parent evenings planned.Schools remain open but the council says it is putting contingency plans in place in case that position changes.Parents are being asked to follow NHS advice regarding any decision to self-isolate children and have been told by the council: ldquoIt is not for the school to advise on the nature of a childrsquos symptoms nor to decide on whether a child should attend or not.

title: council-petitioned-formally-adopt-masterplan-former-cockenzie-power-station-site
story: The plan, revealed in , outlines a potential future for the former Cockenzie Power Station site and was the result of a local authority consultation in  with communities and stakeholders surrounding the site.In the petition, Cockenzie and Port Seton Community Council claims that three years after the consultation, East Lothian Council ldquocontinue to go against the wishes and aspirations of our communities and stakeholders by not formally adopting the masterplan, causing ision, unrest and anger.It says that the councilrsquos ldquounwillingness to act has resulted in a number of plans and proposals, including Skyrorarsquos rocket engine testing facility and Inch Capersquos plan to build a substation, the latter having been approved.It adds: ldquoThe masterplan is our communitiesrsquo vision for the Cockenzie site ndash which includes our communitiesrsquo green space, pathways and parklands.ldquoThe masterplan brings leisure, recreation, tourism, industry and jobs whilst protecting our coastal environment and heritage site.The masterplan includes the creation of office and retail jobs as well as an ldquoenergy quarter, which would bring renewable energy jobs to the site.It also includes a ldquopublic art installation similar to the Kelpies in Falkirk, spaces for festivals, markets and other events, and retains the Battle of Prestonpans site.A community council spokesperson said: ldquoCockenzie and Port Seton Community Council call on East Lothian Councilto do the right thing and formally adopt the masterplan, which came about through guidance from the Scottish Parliament public petitions committee in .ldquoAt that time, East Lothian Council asked the communities bordering the Cockenzie site for their views on the future of the site through a series of workshops and consultation events for the communities and stakeholders.ldquoELC asked the communities answered the outcome is the ELC Peter Brett Cockenzie Masterplan.The Cockenzie Masterplan not only captures the communitiesrsquo vision, it has the potential for upwards of , jobs and also aligns with NPF goals.ldquoOur communities will continue to ask ELC to be as good as their word at the time of our participation in the masterplan consultations ndash to formally adopt the masterplan so that a template exists for the site which clearly reflects the hopes, dreams and aspirations of our communities. Where green space and environment are respected, enhanced and sit alongside industry and energy at Cockenzie, as has been the case for decades and generations.ldquoHad ELC formally adopted the masterplan, Inch Cape would not be located on the coastal frontage of the site, but in Zone , the Energy Quarter, and our communities would not have had the ision and angst caused by the Skyrora proposal to test rocket engines in the midst of communities.ldquoThis week, we read that a large area of land in the Scottish Borders has been passed to the community at a cost to them of pound so that their aspirations for the future can be achieved.ldquoWe ask that ELC either formally adopt the Cockenzie Masterplan or follow that lead and gt the site to the communities.An East Lothian Council spokesperson said: ldquoWe recognise the importance of the sitersquos future and remain committed to working with and updating local stakeholders.ldquoThe former Cockenzie Power Station site has signicant potential for economic development and employment opportunities. The masterplan report ndash which reflects this and set out options for a mixed-use site ndash continues to be an important visionary document.ldquoSince its publication, Inch Cape Offshore Limitedhas received planning permission from Scottish Ministers to build onshore transmission works on part of the site.ldquoAlso, the National Planning Framework continues to include Cockenzie as a site of signicance for thermal energy generation.ldquoIt remains the case that we need to understand whether there are any implications for the site arising from the next National Planning Framework, as well as from potential future planning policy considerations and further technical work.ldquoWe see the masterplan report as one of a number of important considerations that will inform the councilrsquos input to the development plan process. The council is also determined that further technical work was required on the viability of port-related development.ldquoUnderstanding the full implications of all of this is key before the future of the whole site can be determined.The plan was originally drawn up by Peter Brett Associates, appointed by East Lothian Council.The petition can be viewed at change.org p east-lothian-council-petitioning-east-lothian-council-to-formally-adopt-the-cockenzie-masterplan

title: coronavirus-museums-castles-shut-try-halt-spread-virus
story: National Museums Scotland, which operates the National Museum of Flight at East Fortune, confirmed that all of its venues closed from pm on Tuesday.Alongside the Museum of Flight, it also manages National Museum of Scotland, the Museum of Rural Le and the National War Museum.A National Museums Scotland spokeswoman said: ldquoIn response to the impact of Covid-we have made the decision to close all our museums to the public from Tuesday, March , at pm until further notice.ldquoThis will include the National Museum of Scotland, the National Museum of Flight, the National Museum of Rural Le and the National War Museum at Edinburgh Castle.ldquoAll scheduled exhibitions and events will be postponed until further notice, including the display of the Declaration of Arbroath.ldquoWe will make a further announcement once new display dates have been agreed.ldquoThe national collections within our care will continue to be monitored and made secure during this time.Meanwhile, all staffed Historic Environment Scotland properties in East Lothian, including Dirleton Castle and Tantallon Castle, are also closed.A spokesperson for Historic Environment Scotlandsaid: ldquoIn light of updated Scottish Government advice regarding coronavirus, we have taken the decision to close public access to our staffed properties and offices until further notice, with effect from pm on Wednesday, March .ldquoAll planned public events will also be postponed until further notice.ldquoThe safety of our staff, visitors and partners is of paramount importance and we have taken this decision in line with the latest Scottish Government advice.ldquoOur seasonal sites will not be opening as normally scheduled in April . However, our unstaffed sites will be open and are free to access.All East Lothian Councilrsquos museums have also shut: these are John Muirrsquos Birthplace in Dunbar, the John Gray Centre museum in Haddington, Dunbar Town House Museum and Gallery and Prestongrange Museum at Prestonpans ndash the latter two are currently closed for the winter season but will not open as planned this spring.Musselburgh Museum and the Coastal Communities Museum in North Berwick are also shut until further notice.The Coastal Communities Museum had originally planned to launch its new exhibition on April  ndash those at the museum say they will be ready to welcome the public when it is safe to do so.Barbara Clark, acting chair at the museum, said: ldquoThe health and wellbeing of our visitors, user groups and volunteersis our highest priority.ldquoGiven the fast-moving coronavirus outbreak, as a precautionary measure, we are postponing our  exhibition launch event that was due to take place on April  and postponing the seasonal opening of the museum itself, until further notice.Elsewhere, Muirfield Riding Therapyat West Fenton closed its doors on Tuesday with immediate effect.The closure includes the cancellation or postponement of all fundraising events until the end of May.Michelle Sutton, chair, said: ldquoAs has always been the case, the health and well being of our riders and volunteers is the priority in our decision-making process.ldquoWith the recent Government announcements, we feel we can no longer operate our riding therapy sessions.ldquoI know that this will be really disappointing to those people who will miss the last two weeks of their terms riding.ldquoWe are already getting calls about when we will reopen ndash the honest answer is we simply do not know.ldquoWe will review again on a regular basis but I do not expect to open before June  and so unlikely to offer regular sessions until after the summer holidays. If you need to get in touch please drop us an email and we will respond as soon as we can.

title: coronavirus-changes-waste-recycling-collections-announced
story: This is due to staff shortages as a result of the coronavirus outbreak.Green and blue recycling boxes will still be emptied on their usual day but, rather than both being emptied at the same time, the green box will be emptied on the first fortnight and the blue box the second fortnight.There will be no more brown bin collections as these have been suspended until further notice.Food waste and green bins for non-recyclable waste will still be collected as usual but the council urge that containers are placed out on the morning of collection by am.Where staffing allows, the council will try and honour any special uplt collections that have been booked.If items have not been collected by pm on the booked day, take them off the kerbside and contact the council to arrange an alternative date.Recycling centres are still open as normal and limits on vans and trailers remain in place however, some centres may close at short notice.

title: coronavirus-loans-offered-help-east-lothian-businesses-survive
story: Loan lsquoholidaysrsquo are also available on request for companies with an existing ELI Ltd loan.Councillor John McMillan, East Lothian Council Provost and member of the Board of Directors of ELI, said: ldquoI am sure financial support of any kind to businesses will be welcome at this time of great uncertainty, so Irsquom delighted that ELI can offer this."It is a worrying time for businesses of all sizes so itrsquos important that they get as much support as possible to weather the crisis and come out and flourish at the other side."I would encourage any eligible East Lothian businesses to take advantage of this as soon as possible.ldquoEast Lothian Council and ELI has a great record of local business support, including our highly successful East Lothian Gtcard Scheme and Business Gateway service."During this time, I would encourage businesses and iniduals to keep an eye on the dedicated webpage eastlothian.gov.uk coronavirus which will be regularly updated and contains advice on East Lothian Council services affected by Covid-, plus useful links to other organisations, including other sources of business and inidual financial support.ELI is a not-for-profit organisation which sits at armrsquosto East Lothian Council. The fund is managed by employees of the council but governed by a board of directors. The board comprises two East Lothian councillors and three private sector business people who provide their time free of charge to the company. It is authorised and regulated by the Financial Conduct Authority .Loans are available up to pound,, interest free with a holiday repayment period of four months. There is a five per cent arrangement fee to be paid up front and the loan will have a term of  months after the holiday period has ended. It is open to existing businesses only that have been trading for more than two years and have employees.Decisions on loans will be made within seven days and with funds can be paid within  hours.All applications and paperwork will be done via email and arrangement fee and loan award will be paid by bank transfer.

title: north-berwick-named-top-10-places-live-scotland

title: coronavirus-enjoyleisure-close-county-sports-facilities
story: In a statement yesterdayevening , BillAxon, chief executive of enjoyleisure, said: "To slow the spread of Covid-,the general public are being advised to stay at home as much as possible and avoid unnecessary social contact."The health and safety of our visitors and staff is our number one priority."We have taken the extremely dficult decision to close our facilities to the public temporarily and will continually monitor the advice from government so that we are in a good position to re-open as quickly as possible when appropriate."We would like to take this opportunity to thank our customers for their continued loyalty and support, and give special mention to our team of incredible colleagues and their continued dedication and commitment to the delivery of enjoyleisure services.From close of business on Friday,enjoyleisure will closeits sports centres and swimming pools, pitches andpavilions, MeadowmillAthletics Arena andits climbing wall at Tranent.Enjoyleisure-managed golf coursesMusselburgh Old Linksand Winterfield, Dunbar, will remain open to the public for now.All fitness and swimming lesson membership customers will have their monthly direct debit payments reduced to poundper month to cover bank and administration costs.Whileall childrenrsquos and adultscoached activity programmes -including gymnastics, trampolining, climbing, and swimming lessons - will cease tomorrow.All upcoming events, hosted by enjoyleisure or other external organisations at enjoyleisure facilities,have been cancelled or postponed.

title: coronavirus-scottish-seabird-centre-closed
story: The closure came into effect yesterdayand it is not known how long it will last.In a statement, Susan Davies, chief executive of the Seabird Centre, said: ldquoIn view of the latest Scottish Government and Public Health Scotland advice, it is with regret that we have to advise our members and visitors that the Scottish Seabird Centre is closing its doors for the time-being."The safety and wellbeing of our staff, volunteers and visitors is of paramount importance to us at this time.ldquoWe are immensely grateful for all the kind words and offers of support we have received since reopening our newly refreshed Discovery Experience and Learning Hub last year.ldquoMany visitors who have dropped in over the last few days have also told us just how much they also enjoy coming into the centre to socialise. We are sorry that we cannot continue to offer our services just now.ldquoYour continued support has meant a lot to our dedicated frontline staff team, at this uncertain time, and importantly has helped support the conservation and education work that charity delivers.ldquoDuring the closure of our visitor centre, our dedicated team will continue to work behind the scenes on project resources, new interactives and to offer new digital resources for members and participants in our activities and events.ldquoWe will keep you up to date with these as they become available via our social media channels. We are also exploring options for appropriate outdoor activities and flexible use of our cafeacute and gt shop whilst closed.ldquoIf you have any queries please do get in touch via info@seabird.org or by calling the office   and leaving a voice message. One of the team will get back to you, although it may take a little longer than usual.ldquoWe will continue to closely monitor the official advice and will keep you updated on our position through our social media channels and website.ldquoWe hope to be able to welcome you back in the near future. In the meantime please stay safe and well.Some of the countyrsquos other big attractions, including several museums and historic castles, announced their closures earlier this week.

title: coronavirus-schools-across-east-lothian-now-closed
story: East LothianCouncil says it is opening a number of childrenrsquos hubs in each of its school cluster areas for youngsters whose parents are identied as key workers or who are vulnerable.The local authority intends to use digital technology to continue lessons for youngsters who were sent home with packs of school work, including books and usernames and passwords to access Google classrooms.A youth football club is also opening its clubhouse for young people who cannot access the internet to connect free for homework.Preston Athletic YFC, based in Prestonpans, have invited children along between pm and pm during the week, with food and drink also being supplied to the youngsters.The club said: ldquoAs of Monday, March , we will open the clubhouse Monday to Friday,  pm. We welcome children who do not have internet access at home to come along and use our internet free off charge to do homework they must bring their own tablet or laptop.ldquoWe will give all children a free juice and biscuit, adults can have a free hot drink. Children can also havea kick about on the Gthey wish.One of the clubrsquos coaches has offered to produce soup and sandwiches for children who attend and Sugar Rush Creations has offered to provide all youngsters who are doing homework in the clubhouse with free popcorn.Meanwhile, East Lothian Council has announced it will have childrenrsquos hubs at the following schools: Dunbar Primary School St Maryrsquos Primary School Haddington Primary School Law Primary School, North BerwickPreston Tower Primary School , PrestonpansSandersonrsquos Wynd Primary School, Tranentand Pinkie St Peterrsquos Primary School, Musselburgh.The hubs are expected to be available to children who have at least one parent identied as a key worker and no other adult at home, and will also oversee the distribution of free school meals to eligible children and continue providing support for learning to children with additional support needs.The councilrsquos chief operating officer for education Lesley Brown said:ldquoThis is an extremely challenging time for our school communities, including parents, carers, children and staff. Irsquod like to thank everyone for the support you have given our teams in recent days.ldquoClearly the unprecedented decision to close all schools in Scotland by close of play todaypresents major logistical dficulties and inconvenience for families. title: coronavirus-churches-urged-stop-services-prevent-spread-virus
story: A spokesperson for the Church of Scotland said on Tuesday: ldquoThe Scottish Governmentnow advisesthat people should minimise social contact by avoiding crowded areas and large gatherings, including religious congregations, and smaller gatherings.ldquoThe Church of Scotland now asks, in the strongest terms, that all gatherings for worship should cease until further notice.ldquoOther Scottish churches are taking similar actions."This obviously includes Easter services. Some Presbyteries have already instructed this action. This will include, but not be restricted to: housegroups, meetings for youth work, and church cafes.ldquoIt will still be possible for an inidual to offer a livestream of a sermon and prayers.ldquoChurch buildings can be kept open as a place for people to come and pray.Notices should be clearly displayedasking that visitors observe robust hand hygiene, including washing their hands on entry to the church.On weddings and funerals, the Church said that ldquosensitive conversations will need to take place between those affected.The Rev Alison McDonald, from St Maryrsquos Parish Church, Haddington, sent a message to her congregation after the Church of Scotland called for services to be cancelled.She said weekly readings, prayers and reflections would be posted online and plans are being consideredto open the church building for ldquopersonal prayer as the coronavirus crisis continues.The Scottish Episcopal Churchhas also asked its clergy to cease church services.The Most Rev Dr Mark Strange, Primus of the SEC, said: ldquoThis is a dficult time for many people some are fearful for themselves or their relatives, while others want to know how to help stem the spread of the virus.ldquoOur guidance is given not just to address medical concerns but also with pastoral concern being uppermost in our hearts and minds, particularly the care of the vulnerable in our congregations and communities.Church buildings will be allowed to stay open for private prayer. The church will also deliver a video service of the Eucharist every Sunday through its website for those wanting to worship at home.The Catholic Church has cancelled public Masses across Scotland from Thursday and they will not take place until further notice.Masses will still be said in private in churches but not in front of parishioners live streaming will be in place and available where possible.Catholic churches themselves will not be closed completely to allow time for private prayer.

title: weightlifting-headteacher-earns-podium-position-international-event
story: Lynda Banks represented Great Britain at the European Masters Classic Powerlting Championships in France last Monday .The Cockenzie Primary School headteacher lted a whopping  kilogrammes across the three events in the age -,  kilogrammes category, to come home with two bronze medals from the competition in Albi, near Toulouse.Ms Banksrsquo powerlting prowess came about ldquoby pure chance.She had started training at a gym in Inverness when she was , with a view to being strong enough to complete a chin-up.That was successfully achieved and a love of deadlting followed, with the title: explained-difference-self-isolating-social-distancing
story: As spring begins the days are getting longer and warmer, and people are getting the urge to venture outside of their homes after winter.But amid the spread of coronavirus, many people are not sure whether it is safe for them to get out in the open air, or whether they have to stay inside.Here is the dference between social distancing, and social isolating - and what it means for you.Who needs to self isolate The governmentrsquos advice is that anyone who is experiencing symptoms of coronavirus - a dry cough, fever, or dficulty breathing - must self-isolate for a two week period.Anyone classied as lsquovulnerablersquo also has to self-isolate. This includes people over , as well as people with underlying conditions that could make the symptoms of coronavirus worse.Unfortunately for these people, self-isolation means not leaving your house - making going walks outside or meeting friends an impossibility. But the government does say people who are self-isolating can keep windows open to get fresh air.Whatrsquos social distancing The government is advising everyone who is not currently self-isolating to still practise social distancing.This means not meeting with friends and family, staying away from crowded areas, avoiding all non-essential travel, and working from home where possible.Luckily for these people, there is no restriction on going for walks outside. The government website actually encourages people to get plenty of exercise and fresh air.ldquoAt times like these, the website reads, ldquoit can be easy to fall into unhealthy patterns of behaviour which in turn can make you feel worse."Its only warning is not to get too close to other people when outside, asking walkers to stay at least two metres away from each other.Coronavirus: the facts by the World Health Organisation and the NHSWhat is coronavirus COVID- is a respiratory illness that can affect lungs and airways. It is caused by a virus called coronavirus.What caused coronavirus The outbreak started in Wuhan in China in December  and it is thought that the virus, like others of its kind, has come from animals.How is it spread As this is such a new illness, experts still arenrsquot sure how it is spread. But similar viruses are spread in cough droplets. Therefore covering your nose and mouth when sneezing and coughing, and disposing of used tissues straight away is advised. Viruses like coronavirus cannot live outside the body for very long.What are the symptoms The NHS states that the symptoms are: a dry cough, high temperature and shortness of breath - but these symptoms do not necessarily mean you have the illness. Look out for flu-like symptoms, such as aches and pains, nasal congestion, runny nose and a sore throat. Itrsquos important to remember that some people may become infected but wonrsquot develop any symptoms or feel unwell.What precautions can be taken Washing your hands with soap and water thoroughly. The NHS also advises to cover your mouth and nose with a tissue or your sleevewhen you cough or sneeze put used tissues in the bin immediately and try to avoid close contact with people who are unwell. Also avoiding touching eyes, nose and mouth unless your hands are clean.Government adviceAs of Monday, March , the government advised that everyone should be observing social distancing - avoiding unnecessary travel and working from home where possible. Anyone with a cough or cold symptoms now needs to self-isolate with their entire household for  days.The over s or anyone who is vulnerable or living with an underlying illness are being asked to be extra careful and stay at home to self-isolate.For more information on government advice, please check their website.Should I avoid public places The advice now is to avoid public places and any non-essential travel. Travel abroad is also being advised against for the next  days at least, and many European countries have closed their borders.What should I doI feel unwell Donrsquot go to your GP but instead call NHS  or look online at the coronavirus service that can tell youyou need medical help and what to do next.When to call NHS NHS  should be usedyou feel unwell with coronavirus symptoms, have been in a country with a high risk of coronavirus in the last  days oryou have been in close contact with someone with the virus.

title: skyes-limit-sabhal-mor-ostaig---unique-gaelic-only-college-set-stunning-island-location
story: Situated in the stunningly beautul peninsula of Sleat in the south end of the island, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is a unique Gaelic-only environment and the only college of its kind offering further and higher education through the medium of the language.The college offers a range of provision from beginnersrsquo courses to a PhD, with the flexibility of studying part-time or full-time, on campus or via distance learning. At a crucial time in the survival of the language, graduates have helped create a Gaelic speaking workforce that now holds key posts across a wide range of sectors in Scotland.Sabhal Mograver Ostaig is one of the key partners in fulfilling the governmentrsquos objectives in the National Gaelic Plan, which aims to increase the number of people speaking the language and accelerate the growth of Gaelic.Many people are keen to learn more about the language because of its rich culture and the college provides a wide range of short courses in Gaelic language, song and traditional music. Ceilidhs, workshops, conversation circles and music sessions all create an encouraging atmosphere that bring together students from  countries across five continents.As a modern, innovative college, Sabhal Mograver Ostaig has excellent learning resources on campus including an exceptional library collection, residential student accommodation, broadcast and recording facilities and a Gaelic medium childcare facility on site. It also has a growing international reputation for academic research.The college was founded on the principle of being part of the local and wider community and its activities are greatly enhanced by co-operative links, being home to a number of signicant national creative and cultural projects such as Tobar an Dualchais, Ainmean Agraveite na h-Alba and Cagravenan Graphics Studio. It plays a leading role in the promotion of the Gaelic arts and culture and also offers an international exchange programme with universities in Canada and Ireland.The collegersquos graduates include Seumas Greumach , Chief Executive of An Comunn Gaidhealach, which runs the Royal National Mod, who studied the Cugraversa Comais in  and then ed for another year to study Cagravenan is Cultar na Gagraveidhlig. He went to Sabhal Mograver to improve his language skills and says he would not hold his present job had he not become a fluent speaker.ldquoI was fully immersed in the language at Sabhal Mograver Ostaig, which is essential to become fluent in any language. he says. ldquoYou could hear Gaelic being spoken every day, in every situation and that helped me no end in improving my own Gaelic. I gained a great deal of confidence in terms of Gaelic grammar, spelling and writing, all of which has been invaluable in my working le.BBC weather presenter, Joy Dunlop, is another graduate of the college who says the fluency in Gaelic she developed at the college has given her many opportunities that she otherwise would not have had.She studied Gaelic as a second language when she was a pupil at Oban High School then decided to do her sixth year at the college. She initially planned to stay for just one year to do the Cugraversa Comais but loved it so much she stayed for four, graduating with a BAin Cagravenan agus Cultar na Gagraveidhlig .ldquoAttending Sabhal Mograver was a revelation for me, she says. ldquoThe education I received was unparalleled.ldquoThe personal support and guidance I received from all the staff was of the highest level and I always felt that our teachers were genuinely invested in both the language itself and our progress.ldquoBeing immersed in the language is definitely the best way to learn, dficult as it could be at times, and having the opportunity to speak Gaelic in both the classes and the community was a real help to me.ldquoSimply,you genuinely want to learn Gaelic, there is no better place to do so than Sabhal Mograver Ostaig. Tha i math agus tha i math dhut!

title: coronavirus-scotland-tourism-boss-left-speechless-highland-hotels-decision-sack-evict-workers
story: A letter to workers at the Coylumbridge Hotel in Aviemore - owned by Britannia Hotels - emerged on Thursday night, which terminated employment and told affected staff to leave their accommodation immediately.The hotel firm blamed an administrative error and said theyThe move comes amid the global coronavirus outbreak, which has so far killed six people in Scotland.:Rail timetable reduced from MondayWhen contacted by the PA news agency, a member of staff at the hotel said some people have been affected by the redundancies but the reported numbers were inaccurate.The decision drew ire from politicians, with Scottish Finance Secretary Kate Forbes and Inverness, Nairn, Badenoch and Strathspey MP Drew Hendry condemning the move.Marc Crothall, chief executive of the Scottish Tourism Alliance, told BBCs Good Morning Scotland on Friday: "I was absolutely speechless as to the actions that Britannia Hotels have taken."There is huge anger among our industry as well, this is not reflective of how all of our businesses that we know and our members behave."Hundreds and hundreds have come out to condemn what is a deplorable action."Mr Crothall confirmed another of Aviemores hotel operators, Macdonald Hotels, has stepped in to offer accommodation to the Coylumbridge staff.He added: "At this time, this is about pulling together."The letter to staff said: "Taking the latest government advice, this letter is to confirm that with effect from March  , your employment has been terminated as your services are no longer required."Your final payslip will include all hours worked up to and including your final day, together with any accrued holidays not already taken and one weeks pay in lieu of notice."You are asked to vacate the hotel accommodations immediately, ing any company property to John Macfarlane, hotel controller, before leaving the hotel."I would like to take this opportunity to wish you every success in securing future employment and thank you for your time at Britannia Hotels."It came just days after the Scottish Government announced measures to help protect the hospitality sector during the coronavirus outbreak, with a promise of % business rates relief.Ms Forbes described the treatment of staff by Britannia as "heartless" on Twitter, while a post on Mr Hendrys Facebook page was inundated with offers of work and accommodation for the workers affected.:CalMac halts ferry bookings for next four monthsHe said: "Got to say, where the letter from the Coylumbridge Hotel was shocking, it is just fabulous the way the wider community is rallying round with offers of support for those affected on my FB page."Well done to our communities."A spokesman for Britannia Hotels said:"With regards to the current situation regarding staff at our Coylumbridge Hotel and being asked to vacate their staff accommodation. Unfortunately, the communication sent to these employees was an administrative error."We have approximately  live in staff who did not receive this communication. Unfortunately it was Mr Garcia and a few other members of staff who received the incorrect correspondence, due to this administration error. All affected employees are being immediately contacted.""We apologise for any upset caused."

title: coronavirus-social-measures-needed-for-least-year
story: The Scientic Pandemic Influenza Group on Modelling agreed on Monday that, while the severity of measures could alternate during the period, ldquostricter measures would need to be enforced for at least half of the year in order to keep cases at a level the NHS can cope with.Strict measures could include school closures and social distancing for everyone, while less restrictive measures include isolating cases and households.:Coronavirus in Scotland: Number of cases increase by  as tally surpasses The Government published the papers on Friday ndash a day after Prime Minister Boris Johnson said he expects the tide to be turned in the fight against Covid- within  weeks.The report states: ldquoIt was agreed that the addition of both general social distancing and school closures to case isolation, household isolation and social distancing of vulnerable groups would be likely to control the epidemic when kept in place for a long period."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Coronavirus: How has sport been affected ","description": "Coronavirus: How has sport been affected ","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media zduDsNP poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests zduDsNP.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": ldquoIt was agreed that a policy of alternating between periods of more and less strict social distancing measures could plausibly be effective at keeping the number of critical care cases within capacity.ldquoThese would need to be in place for at least most of a year. Under such a policy, at least half of the year would be spent under the stricter social distancing measures.The document says that the triggers for measures to be put in place or lted could y according to dferent regions.There would be a two to three-week delay between measures being put into place and their impact being felt in intensive care units, it added.On Thursday, the Prime Minister said the tide on Covid- could be turned in the next  weeks but added he could not promise that the UK would definitely be on a downward slope from the peak of the virus.He said: ldquoI cannot stand here and tell you that by the end of June we will be on the downward slope.ldquoItrsquos possible but I simply canrsquot say that for certain. Of course not, we donrsquot know where we are, we donrsquot know how long this thing will go on for but what I can say is that this is going to be finite, we will turn the tide and I can see how to do it within the next  weeks.:Coronavirus: Wetherspoons chief Tim Martin condemned for saying shutting pubs is "over the top"It comes as Chancellor Rishi Sunak plans to announce more emergency measures for workers.He has been under pressure from Labour, unions and even senior Tory MPs to do more to help workers and the stalling economy weather the crisis.He will reveal new measures on Friday at the daily Covid- press conference in Downing Street, where he is expected to be joined by Mr Johnson.Elsewhere:ndash A third person who tested positive for coronavirus in Wales has died.ndash The FTSE  rose by more than % in early trading on Friday.ndash Conservative MP Maria Caulfield announced she was ing to her job as a nurse alongside her political role.ndash A man was arrested on the Isle of Man for failing to follow its coronavirus self-isolation rules.ndash The competition watchdog said it will clamp down on retailers using the coronavirus outbreak as an opportunity to exploit customers.ndash The Changing the Guard ceremonies at Buckingham Palace, St Jamesrsquos Palace and Windsor Castle are being postponed until further notice.ndash Downing Street expects post-Brexit talks to continue despite Boris Johnsonrsquos chief negotiator David Frost showing symptoms of the coronavirus. His EU counterpart, Michel Barnier, tested positive on Thursday.ndash The death toll from the coronavirus in Spain now stands at , and nearly , people have been infected.It comes as Health Secretary Matt Hancock said a group of around . million people with serious health conditions will receive specic advice on what to do to keep themselves safe from coronavirus.At present, anyone with an underlying health condition such as those who usually receive an NHS flu jab, people with weakened immune systems and anyone over  is told to be ldquoparticularly stringent in following social distancing measures.But those who are at even higher risk of severe illness from Covid-, including recipients of donor organs, those on active chemotherapy or radiotherapy, people with blood cancers and those with severe chest conditions, will be given more tailored advice.Mr Hancock told Sky News: ldquoMany of these people have pre-existing health conditions and so will be very worried right now, and I understand that, and theyrsquoll need very specic sets of action ndash for instance, how do you go about still getting your chemoyou have cancer whilst also social-distancing ldquoIf you have cancer itrsquos particularly important to stay away from other people, but you also of course have got to keep going with your chemotherapy.He added: ldquoThese are some of the most dficult and challenging cases so wersquoll be getting in contact with them, butpeople think that they are on this list and donrsquot receive a communication from the NHS, then they also need to get in contact.Mr Hancock suggested that tougher measures could have to be brought inpeople do not follow the Governmentrsquos advice on social distancing and staying homeill.He told the BBCrsquos Breakfast programme: ldquoWhat I can say is thatpeople follow the advice, stay home, which saves lives, andthey keep apart from others ndash more than two metres, more than six foot ndash then we can tackle this and we can turn the tide.ldquoThe scientists advise that we can turn the tide in  weekspeople follow the advice. If people donrsquot follow the advice, then itrsquoll be longer and we might have to bring more and tougher measures.Mr Hancock said the UK had brought measures in earlier than Italy, which has now suffered more deaths than China.ldquoBut wersquore absolutely clear that,we need to, we have the powers ndash in fact, wersquove got a Bill in front of Parliament now to strengthen those powers further.ldquoBut I think itrsquos far betterpeople follow the advice.Meanwhile, Dawn, a critical care nurse in Yorkshire, has made a tearful appeal to members of the public to stop stripping supermarket shelves of food after she came off a sht and was unable to buy supplies.Chief Nursing Officer for England Ruth May also urged members of the public to play their part in the fight against Covid-.She told Sky News: ldquoThere are many, many nurses like that critical care nurse last night who are working many, many hours.ldquoWersquore asking all supermarkets to allow all of our healthcare workers easy access to buy their food and vegetables.ldquoIrsquod also make a plea for all the public to show a kindness.ldquoWersquove heard that people are spitting at our nurses this is just not right, they are working very hard. I would want to make sure we all play a part in this coronavirus fight.

but people can recoverHe added: ldquoTo all those at home, right now anxious about the days ahead, I say you will not face this alone.Chancellor Rishi Sunak said the coronavirus business interruption loan scheme will now be interest free for  months rather than the six months previously announced.ldquoAnd thanks to the enormous efforts of our critical financial services sector those loans will now be available starting from Monday, he said.Mr Sunak added: ldquoAny employer in the country, small or large, charitable or non-profit, will be eligible for the scheme.The Chancellor made an appeal to bosses to stand by their workers during the coronavirus crisis.ldquoLet me speak directly to businesses: I know itrsquos incredibly dficult out there ndash we in Government are doing everything we can to support you, he said.ldquoThe Government is doing its best to stand behind you and Irsquom asking you to do your best to stand behind our workers.ldquoPlease look very carefully at that support before making any decisions to lay people off, Mr Sunak continued.ldquoItrsquos on all of us.Labour leadership contender Lisa Nandy said the wage guarantee scheme was ldquoreally welcome news from the Chancellor.ldquoFor many businesses it is the leline they need and it will being relief to lots of people.
